reviews.review: I really wanted to love the Golden Sound location... but alas, it seemed a bit forced and even more hipster than I can handle. It serves a nice local community in the downtown area and I'm sure the folks within walking distance love it. Pros: Great open spaces. Easy parking. Great beverages. Solid food options accompany their drink menu.Cons: It's more of an elevated coffee experience than I can handle... or any non-coffee pro. I appreciate the different approach, but maybe be a bit more welcoming and educational with the different varieties.

reviews.name: Kent D.
reviews.review: Wide awake and watching hipsters doing hip things with artisan-selected, block-harvested, estate and shade grown, fair trade, heart made-out-of-foam cappuccinos. A little twee... Kind of mod... Sexy staff.

reviews.name: Rich P.
reviews.review: What a fantastic place.   Incredible attention to detail.  Had best iced coffee I've ever had (intelligentsia pour over) and equal best breakfast sandwich with egg, cheese, bacon, sriracha aioli. Soooo good. I didn't want to leave!

reviews.name: Eileen G.
reviews.review: I had been looking forward to trying BP but since they don't have decaf espresso I couldn't try any coffee drinks as I'm super sensitive to caffeine. Pretty disappointing. So instead I had to get an herbal tea, which was good... But it took about 10 min to get to my table. And it was $4. No one greeted me as I walked in or waited at the counter as is usual coffee shop practice. Cool ambiance at first but it's on the  pretentious side. I felt judged asking for decaf. Can't a girl just like the taste of coffee itself? Also rather loud for conversation. I don't really care to go back. My friend enjoyed her coffee a lot and said it was tasty.

reviews.name: Eric R.
reviews.review: Really enjoyed breakfast here. Had the sausage biscuit with egg, slathered with jam. Sausage patty was great, from local butcher shop down the street, and jam tasted like fresh made. My wife liked the gluten free option of the same, liked it as well. Son enjoyed the biscuits & gravy. Party of 6 had no trouble finding a place to sit together. Option to sit outside. Special brew coffee was pretty good, not fantastic. Hipster atmosphere, nifty decor in old transmission shop. Cool tunes. Large selection of small-batch chocolates. Pricey, though. Family of 4 was $45.

reviews.name: Jordan H.
reviews.review: Coffee is great. Specialty drinks are incredible. Quality is on another level. Atmosphere is cool...Get the vibe that if you order the wrong thing that a barista may laugh at you. That's why 4/5 instead of 5. Good environment to get some work done.

reviews.name: Stephanie M.
reviews.review: I came across this place on Instagram of all places. Took a trip to Nashville, and knew I had to visit. I can see why it's on insta, it's a photogenic place. But that's really a testament to their styling and Americana theme. I mean, they have bandanas for napkins. It's that kind of attention to detail and thoughtfulness that's exhibited throughout the establishment. This location in particular (Gallatin Ave.), is in a renovated automotive shop, with garage doors and a huge open space. It has great lighting, and I love how it connects with the outside as one seamless place. It's a little hard to find this location, as out-of-towners, but you park in front of Local Honey and walk around to the back.The food, was off the chain. I had the BP Breakfast Sandwich - I didn't know a breakfast sandwich could be this freaking good. Fresh bread (more than likely handmade), thick cut bacon, aioli sauce..etc. It was a generous size for a breakfast sandwich and one of the most delicious I've had. I took my time eating and savored every bite. I also had a chocolate donut, which I had no expectations for, but wow. It was fresh take on a classic. It was super soft, airy like a donut should be, and full of flavor. With the added bonus of a homemade marshmallow in the center. The coffee was on the same level of greatness. I had a hot latte with almond milk (which is a huge perk having non dairy options), and my boyfriend had a iced mocha. Both had a nice velvety finish, and great body. It's more expensive then your average coffee place, but it's so worth it. I think the prices are fair, given the amount of attention that goes into everything.They made two big fans out of us. We bought some souvenirs, local chocolates & a barista parlor glass cup. They also sell growers for iced coffee! I didn't purchase it (though I'm regretting it now) but I asked about it, and the lady at the cashier took the time to tell me about how it's made. I should also point out, that when we first arrived, we told them we were from out of town and they took the time to give us the run down and explored the menu (even though there where a few people behind us). I really appreciated that. You can tell the people there love their jobs and it shows. It was a fun experience and we'll will definitely be coming back next time we're in town.

reviews.name: Ryan N.
reviews.review: Always great to find local hidden gems while traveling. The attention to the coffee here is second to none and pretty good food too!

reviews.name: Meredith R.
reviews.review: 1. Get a poptart heated up (So incredibly delicious) 2. The workers are very skilled and know how to make killer coffee 3. The whisky caramel latte was by far the best latte I have ever had EVER (it was not overly sweet and the caramel complemented the flavor of the espresso perfectly...not a butterscotch-y caramel, which is typically the case. 4. The ambiance is relaxed and great for working/chatting with friends

reviews.name: Tamra P.
reviews.review: First morning in Nashville and we found ourselves at the Barista Parlor for coffee and a bit of breakfast.  The vibe was funky and cool, the service excellent.  We each had a cold brew coffee which was superb and breakfast biscuits.  The biscuits were flaky and light topped with homemade peach jam, sausage, and an egg.  So good.

reviews.name: Gabriella L.
reviews.review: Updating my review because the line is always so slow and everything costs a fortune. I'm all about spending good money on good food, but $5.50 for a pour-over before tip is exorbitant. Definitely gonna stop coming here.

reviews.name: Carl M.
reviews.review: This place is a parody of itself. So comically trite in its appearance and operation, that I can't even take it serious!One of many ridiculous scenarios: I asked for a mix of their plain, unsweetened iced tea, and their caffeinated lemon grass iced tea - because I wanted caffeine, but also a little lemon flavor. They refused to mix the two because "they didn't design them that way". I can see that statement holding some relevance for a coffee drink, or anything that's comprised of more than just plain, unsweetened iced tea, but he egotistically kept pushing the point, just to make sure that I understood my own ignorance.I'm not old, out of touch, or unaware of the way that bespoke coffee shops work, I just know that there's a difference between operating a legitimate business that values people, and operating a playground for untalented out-of-work musicians to pretend that they're inventing the world's most important elixir.Don't be fooled by this place...

reviews.name: Ryan P.
reviews.review: 4 stars for ambience. The barista bar is located in the center of the room, with cool seating all around. It was neat to watch them make the drinks, and the drinks themselves were tasty. This place was packed and the line was long on a Saturday, but I would say that's to be expected for the area. They had a neat out door area that I assume is used as a music venue, and their food options were pretty neat for a coffee place.Overall, I will say this is a returnable place and a nice distraction from all the Starbucks around

reviews.name: kristin k.
reviews.review: The ambience is great, but the service is painfully slow. My (tiny) espresso and milk was lackluster at best and everything was overpriced. We couldn't try food because it was going to take at least 1 hour to make BISCUITS AND GRAVY, so instead waited 45 minutes for 3 coffees. This is such a pretentious, douchy place, which I could deal with if they delivered decent service. Will never be back here again.

reviews.name: Chloe M.
reviews.review: So hipster. I mean, I really can't stand it. I was "anti" this place the minute I walked in the door. Denim aprons. Chocolate that was, and I'm quoting, 'maneuvered' in Portland. Coffee is served on little wood planks. Gag me with a spoon. 10 minute wait to order. Then, redemption!  They apologized for the wait and gave us a piece of artisanal caramel. From a customer to a barista, nothing says "thank you" like cash. From a barista to a customer, nothing says "sorry" like free candy.

reviews.name: Todd F.
reviews.review: One of the grooviest coffee spots I've been to - hipster for sure, but not pretentious.Coffee beverages are very well prepared.  Other reviewers have mentioned the prices seem steep.  I say you get what you pay for - this isn't McDonalds, but rather artisan coffee brewed on demand for you.They serve some of the most delicious biscuits I've ever had.  Get the moto biscuit sandwich with sausage,  You won't regret it.Will for sure be back.

reviews.name: Ashley T.
reviews.review: I decided to give this place another shot. I do love supporting small, local businesses and I can't deny how cool barista parlor is. It's in my neighborhood and I want to love it! I would rate the staff alone 5 stars for being very friendly and helpful. But 2 stars for the quality of the beverage I ordered and the price point. YIKES. $6.50 for a tiny espresso with almond milk and some bougie bourbon vanilla syrup in leu of regular vanilla syrup. The drink itself wasn't necessarily bad, but it wasn't six dollars and fifty cents good. If anything, it tasted a tad burnt. I hate this because I wouldn't mind paying that much for a drink if it was delicious. Kind of a bummer. I'm sure I'll eventually go back, I've heard great things about the breakfast sammies, but so far, I haven't been that impressed!

reviews.name: Amanda S.
reviews.review: Love this place! Yes it's hipster-ish but not snarky. All the people working here were so friendly!I normally get a drip or pour over but heck I was on vacation. I splurged and ordered the whiskey caramel. It was really tasty and slightly fancy with a heart of foam on top. My husband had a pour over Ethiopian. He really liked it. I tried it and it was good and strong without a bitter aftertaste. We liked Barista Parlor so much that we came back again the next day.  My husband had the same pour over and I tried a Columbian pour over. Both were excellent. I like the building itself.  It's open, roomy with plenty of seating.  I am back in KC and missing my afternoon cup of coffee at Barista Parlor.

reviews.name: Lesley K.
reviews.review: Good to chill and take in the scene. Coffee is ok. I love the carrot cake donut. There's better macaroons elsewhere. Hot foods not so good. My friends had waffles but didnt like it because they were not warm enough. One got hot chocolate that is not hot. Food is definitely not worth the price. I got here on a Sunday morning. Barely beat the crowd that got in at 9:30ish. There was one cashier and two baristas. Took 15minutes to get my coffee. I think they were under staffed. Lines long but still plenty of seating. Parking is tight. There are spots by the entrance and more at the back.

reviews.name: Courtney S.
reviews.review: Heard good things about this place so brought my momma while she was in town. We both ordered pour over coffee recommended by the barista. It was amazing! I have never had coffee that smooth before in my life. They have some baked goods and a simple breakfast menu. We weren't too hungry so we kept it simple with a biscuit and a macaroon! We got their early so we skipped the line! Would come here again :)

reviews.name: Elizabeth M.
reviews.review: Love, love, love this shop. The coffee is beautifully crafted and the staff is incredibly kind. My dad also frequents this place almost every day and he Is quite the coffee snob. Highly recommend.

reviews.name: Helen V.
reviews.review: Barista Parlor on Gallatin was one of the first "fancy" coffee shops in town.  It has lived up to the hype, and I'm glad that they carry some of my favorite beans from the West Coast.  The biscuits and bourbon latte are also worth it.

reviews.name: John W.
reviews.review: Overpriced and snobby, but good. What can I say? If you like Bon Iver, herbal infused hoosy-whatses, and transplant hipsters from Brooklyn, it's perfect. If not, you may want to just go to Frothy Monkey.

reviews.name: Joanna L.
reviews.review: This is my second visit to Barista Parlor. Although I love the ambience I can't justify paying an arm and a leg for coffee. Friday afternoon was not very busy but getting our drinks took about 15 to 20 minutes. I did end up getting a hot chlocolate during this visit and was pleasantly surprised. Definitely recommended to visit when in East Nashville but hard to make it a regular place to frequent with its exorbitant prices.

reviews.name: Scotty H.
reviews.review: Yup, it's definitely a "Hip" place for "Hispters" to look "Hip". Unfortunately, they placed all their efforts on the vibe and not in the products. They are VERY proud of their offerings, however, given the price.I can't speak for their coffee, however, because my blood pressure situation doesnt allow me to have caffine, and THEY DON'T OFF ANY DECAFFEINATED COFFEE OR ESPRESSO!!!! All I could have was some decaf Plum Tea, which was actually fairly tasty but not anything close to what I wanted. I can speak for the decor. It's in what appears to be an old jiffy lube type garage. Hard walls, high ceilings, VERY echo-ey and loud. The furniture, again, is designed to look cool, but is absolutely NOT conducive for comfort and conversation. The side tables against the walls have a huge cable attaching them to the wall. They cut right through your line of sight to the person you're sitting with. WTF? So, if you're a poser and want to appear like you should be in L.A. instead of Nashville AND you have money to burn, go here. Otherwise, stick with the MANY other great coffee places in Nashville like, "Edgehill Cafe", "Bongo Java", or "Portland Brew".

reviews.name: Gina H.
reviews.review: This place is rad. I currently live in San Francisco, and have lived in Portland. Both places have great coffee shops and beans. Barista Parlor is right up there with the Bay and City of Roses. The food was tasty (I'm a vegetarian) and my latte  was great. Also, the service was quick and friendly. That and most of the folks working here are totally babes. Babes with beards. Next time I'm in Nashville I am totally returning.

reviews.name: Eliza R.
reviews.review: The only way to truly enjoy this place is if you forget everything you already know about coffee shops. It's a new experience, so don't go in expecting to see what you have seen before.

reviews.name: Michelle P.
reviews.review: Surprise surprise when you come to this place at an odd hour and the line is out the door! Don't fret though, most of the queue build up is due to the fact that most people don't know what they want when they get here and there are only two physical menus on site. (I highly suggest at least creating an online menu of standard coffees and breakfast fare to remedy that.) Still it moves at a decent pace, just don't expect it to move like a fast food joint--you're here for quality remember?Coffee is ridiculously well made and their biscuit sandwiches are pretty good to boot. Like others have noted it's a bit pricey but it is in a little bubble of trendy art and and it's ambiance kind of is a dead give away that this won't be a hole in the wall sort of place. It's very modern with some really good music to match. If I knew what I was getting myself into I would have brought a book or journal and lingered but hey!--whether you're there to catch up with friends, grab a bite to eat or people watch with a balanced cup of joe, it's definitely a nice little oasis. They also have a wide and tasty looking selection of pastries and chocolates I plan to sample next time I'm on that side of town.

reviews.name: Austin G.
reviews.review: Barista Parlor is what you'd imagine a coffee shop in East Nashville would be like.  It has seating outside on a wooden deck and the inside is huge with wooden long tables, cool lights, and hipster/southern decor. The coffee itself is pretty good and they use coffee from different roasters from Stumptown to Counter Coulture. They have strong wifi and a lot of seating.The thing that prevented a five star rating is the people: both the staff and their customers. Everyone were the type of hipsters that are elitist and don't smile at you since they are judging everyone who walks in. Not friendly people at all. Come on Nashville!

reviews.name: Johnny T.
reviews.review: Barista Parlor is, definitely, the sort of place which requires multiple visits to get. The first time I came here, I was pretty turned off. Unfortunately, the reviews which mention unfriendly baristas, confusing signage and nonchalant-to-hostile service really rang true. I can't imagine this sort of experience was/is the intention of the founder. I can't understand why this seems to be such a pervasive problem. In any event, I came and was quite satisfied never to return.Fast forward to a rainy evening, bad traffic and guests in need of a coffee break. I breathed deeply and ventured to BP once again. This time, I had a much more pleasant experience. The barista behind the counter was engaging. He answered questions, offered suggestions and made my party feel appreciated for having chosen to give this store money. Okay. I get it. Much better.I'd recommend going for one of the seasonal blends. On my first visit, I had the whiskey caramel and I couldn't finish it. For my tastes, it was too cloying and the flavor profiles within the cup competed, rather than worked together. It was not enjoyable. Upon my second visit, I ordered a seasonal tea blend I enjoyed much much more. The ordering process goes a bit like this: walk in, claim a seat on the reclaimed wood bench and lowrise table (the build out is nicely done; minimal, but that's the point). Walk to the front and hope that you know what you want. If not, take a gander at one of two (?) printed menus and hope that no one will roll his/her eyes at you for taking a minute. I was lucky enough (upon my second visit) to encounter a barista who answered questions and offered suggestions. As a result, my beverage, food and customer experience was greatly improved from my initial visit. And, speaking of food, go for the homemade pop-tart. My butterscotch chocolate chunk scone was too much for me. Again, for my tastes, the flavor combo curdled a bit in my belly. As you can read from my reviews, my sweet tooth is truth... and this was a pastry I didn't finish. That rarely happens. The pop-tart is a sugar bomb worthy of the calories and cavity risk.The problem with BP is that it can be painfully hip... almost to the point of farce. Parking can be a bit of a chore (tip: drive through to the other side, if entering from Gallatin). Music varies depending on who's working. My first visit's playlist verged on the you-need-Jesus-Tipper-was-right tip. My next visit was a trip down the '90s hip-hop road. I enjoyed that much more. The good thing about Barista Parlor is that it has a definite point of view. The bad part about it is that I don't know if the execution of said point of view is an ultimately sustainable business model. You simply can't make a habit of alienating the people who keep your lights on -- especially when the price point is so deliberate. I'm glad I made a return visit in order to improve my opinion. Would/will others do the same... ?

reviews.name: Dara M.
reviews.review: If you can get over the ridiculous amount of hipster that is Barista Parlor, it's actually pretty fantastic. I'm guessing it was previously a garage...they have these giant garage doors that they open so it's bright and airy inside.The decor is awesome--everything from taxidermic animals to a giant tile mosaic to vintage flags.  There are long, communal tables filled with artists working away on their giant MacBook Pros.I had a vanilla latte (amazing--not even close to being too sweet, and tasted like actual vanilla), and the Southern Frenchman, a buttermilk biscuit with smoked ham, eggs, Swiss, smoked paprika, and raspberry jam. Hands down the best iteration of a biscuit sandwich I've ever consumed in my life. I'm not even joking. The biscuit was buttery and rich, the ham was salty and smoky, the eggs fluffy, and everything perfectly complemented by the sweet raspberry jam. Sigh. I could go on.

reviews.name: Mad I.
reviews.review: Bourbon Vanilla Latte $6.  Most expensive coffee I've had, but I will say, it was the best!  Sooo flavorful! Worth the wait...and we waited, pretty solid 5-10 in line and 10-12 after..... Really cool inside, loved it!!!!!!

reviews.name: Kristen C.
reviews.review: Real questions for BP management: do any girls work at the shop? Is this some kind of cool 'boys only' club where everyone has tight fades and rides motorcycles? Why on earth do you not serve Americanos? No espresso? No hot water? Please explain the $5 pricing of a cold brew. Cold brews max out at $3.75 in the NYC coffee world, land of pretentious and expensive drinks. Is there any reason a capp and a cold brew should take 20 minutes when there are three people working? NO.Long story short, we tried this place twice while visiting from Brooklyn. One of us is high up within the third wave coffee world. We've had our fair share of delicious capps and lattes. Take it from us: SKIP THIS PLACE. It's not concerned with product. It's not concerned with customer service. Unless aesthetic and/or finding the perfect filter for your Instagram photo is your thing, go to Crema.

reviews.name: Rachel H.
reviews.review: Super atmosphere and really great coffee.  I loved the East Nash location immediately as it was asthetically beautiful.  We had to wait in a very long line (right after lunch on a Saturday) and it took about 5-10 minutes after that to get our coffee.  The barista brought them to our table and the espresso was fantastic, really great and worth the attitude I got from the barista when ordering my coffee with a side of questions.This is a great space to work too as surprisingly the noise wasn't crazy, even with the abundance of steelwork throughout the space.  It was busy and I was still able to get a lot of work done and stay focused.  There may have been some short breaks on account of people watching, please make some time to do the same.

reviews.name: Brad N.
reviews.review: One of the best spots for all things coffee, coffee-cocktails and pastries. My favorite of the two locations but only for atmosphere.

reviews.name: Wynter F.
reviews.review: You will definitely miss this place unless you know where to look. I definitely almost drove past it but because of previous yelpers I knew that it was behind a women's clothing store. Parking can get a little hectic. You can't park at the store in front of it but the parking lot for Barista Parlor is kind of small. I hate parallel parking and there wasn't any open spots anyway so I circled around a couple of times until I found someone coming out of their parking lot. The shop is huge and was very crowded. There was a line which I expected but was not bothered by it at all since I knew the wait would be worth it. I did not find that the guy taking the orders was rude or unfriendly at all. It sucks that so many people have had that kind of experience but I already knew what I wanted walking in since I had heard yelpers talk about the Iced Bourbon Barrel Vanilla Latte. I got up to the guy taking the order and told him what I wanted drink-wise along with a campfire scone made with marshmallows, chocolate and graham crackers along with a strawberry basil macaroon. He asked if I was going to be eating there or taking everything to go and then asked for my name for the order. I have yet to actually try the scone or macaroon because I had already eaten so much and wanted to eat them later. I will give my opinion on those later!The iced latte I ordered was so good. It was smooth and, granted, I am not a  coffee expert but you could tell that the coffee was the way coffee is supposed to be. I would love to try just their regular coffee one day. I am sure that it is just as good. Barista Parlor has my heart in just one visit.

reviews.name: Stefan K.
reviews.review: Hype about Barista Parlor abounds around Nashville and even into other states. As a Portland native who watched the coffee scene grow up and evolve into what it is today, who sat in Stumptown cafes twice a week for years, who worked for a high-end coffee roaster and who recently moved to Nashville, I hope that I have some credibility to bear. I first visited Barista Parlor in late 2013 or early 2014. I ordered a V60 cup of some single-origin by Madcap. While the profile appeared decent, it was shockingly watered-down. I thought it was a joke and it was a bit insulting after paying a premium for it, but I was down the road and not willing to go back and wait in line to fight about it.In early 2015, I went and waited outside, but sent in someone with $50, to get me a mocha with Stumptown Hair Bender and a bag of Fourbarrel Guatemala. Off we went down the road and I sampled my mocha in dismay and eventually disgust. To add insult to injury, my change was exactly $20 and, at that point, I felt a strong desire to go in and tell them something about themselves. Instead, I'm here to put them in their rightful place in a more public way. If you're not from Portland, you probably don't know that espresso shots in all Stumptown cafes are made with their own Hair Bender blend of beans. I consumed it in all manner of drinks, at ALL Stumptown locations in Portland, served up by many different baristas for years. I have also frequented any number of other independent cafes in Portland that serve Stumptown exclusively. So, when I say that I KNOW what Hair Bender is and what it should be, hear me.My "Hair Bender" mocha from Barista Parlor was not cohesive, lacked the subtle touch of sweetness I expect in a mocha and lacked any real body. In fact, in spite of my years of experience with this espresso blend, I would have never guessed that it was Hair Bender. It was absolutely shameful, in my careful analysis.Now about the Fourbarrel beans: At home, for drip brewing, I use tools by Technivorm, Bonavita, Rancilio and Baratza. (I also use a Bodom French-press once in a while.) I use filtered water and the whole bit. I brewed up the Fourbarrel coffee that probably cost me $25 of the $30 I spent the night before. Was it amazing and mind-blowing? No. It was decent, but I expect much more at that price point. I played with the machines and there was no sweet spot I could find. This is not $25 coffee - not even close. Once again, pitching it as such is shameful.You need to know that I did not first walk into Barista Parlor feeling cynical or convinced of all the hype; I just wanted some quality coffee. (My friends and I frequented Stumptown not because it was "cool," but because the cups never disappointed.I can appreciate the atmosphere at Barista Parlor, apart from hints of SoCal-style pretense. However, at the end of the day - and with a name such as theirs - the coffee should be the main attraction and stand up on its own, regardless of atmosphere or conjecture from uninformed hipster hopefuls who consider Charbucks or Ugly Mugs to be points of reference.  So, if you want a quality cup of coffee in Nashville, keep looking. (For example: Eighth & Roast or Crema.)  If you want to throw your money away on coffee-flavored water, so that you can be seen at Barista Parlor or say that you were there, knock yourselves out.

reviews.name: Bridget H.
reviews.review: I wish I could give this place 10 stars for coffee.  This was definitely the best coffee I have had in Nashville (Crema a close second).  I love the ambiance and the food is tasty too!  I tried the eggs and Benton's bacon with a side of cornbread- Triple YUM!

reviews.name: Nathan C.
reviews.review: LOVE the style of this place but that's about it.  I get exactly what they are going for here but the service is ridiculously slow and unorganized.  I only ordered cold brew and it was delicious but was a long wait.  I only ordered that because I heard someone else order it, there is only one menu on a clipboard to look at and its at the register so by the time you get up there, it's a pain to sit and figure out what you want while the crowd continues to grow.Here's my major problem though:  I don't live in Nashville but love getting a mug from the cool coffee shops I visit in my travels so I figured I'd get one and some beans.  There are no prices listed on their merch so I figured it out when I got to the register....I was thinking for one mug and a half pound of beans, it would be maybe $15-20.....it was over $50!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  After looking at the receipt I realized the little uninteresting mug was $25 itself!!!!!  And when I got home, I found rocks in my coffee beans!!!I think I'll stick to frothy monkey on my next visit

reviews.name: Katie L.
reviews.review: As others have conveyed, Barista Parlor is hipster as all get-out. I won't get into it. Instead, I'll share why I won't be returning.1. The service is very slow -- The long line leaves you with nothing to do during your wait, since there are no menus at the line's start. Instead, you don't have a chance to decide what you want until you get to the register, where the one menu is kept. This causes an extreme bottleneck in service.2. The coffee isn't special, and it's expensive for not being unique. The coffee drink I ordered was served in a short champagne flute, not nearly enough for a morning drink, which was my intention.3. Parking is difficult.4. It's very loud indoors.5. There's no welcome upon your entry.6. The person at the register left when I got to the line's front, and she was gone for 5-6 minutes while I stood waiting.After my experience here on a weekday, I went to Frothy Monkey around lunchtime -- greeted when I walked in the door, stack of menus to read while waiting in line, a smile shared once getting to the line's front ... an all-around better, more comfortable, inviting experience. Barista Parlor is exclusive, not inclusive. Pass.

reviews.name: Chandler C.
reviews.review: I feel pretty indignant reading the 1-2 star reviews. Commons complaints about Barista Parlor seems to be that it a) takes too long and b) is expensive. I will address both of these complaints in order. Response to taking too long: yes, it takes longer than starbucks, it takes longer than most cafés. Barista Parlor is not like most cafés, they spend a lot of time making sure that the drinks are prepared carefully, a characteristic that is evident in their products. If you don't have enough time to sit down and chill out, you probably shouldn't come here. Response to being "exorbitant": two things. First, Barista Parlor is comparatively expensive, there is no denying this. However, they are not being at all deceitful, nor is the price range beyond the "$$" (i.e. $11-$30) rating yelp has it listed as. A cup of coffee is around 4-6, speciality drinks can be more expensive. Food is around $10, not huge portions but very high quality. I have a feeling a lot of these bad reviews are coming from people who were improperly referred to Barista Parlor. If you aren't crazy about coffee, if you're a tourist on a tight budget, or if you really don't see the point in paying any more than the minimum for products in general, you should not waste your time here.

reviews.name: Derek W.
reviews.review: Barista Parlor is an epicenter of style and chic with a lineup of four-star coffees from around the country to choose from and a superb but small food menu on the side.  Perpetually packed and relentlessly hip, the large interior and exterior space here is perfect for hanging out (sometimes in long lines), people watching, and gazing at the beautiful creative art and the reclaimed industrial wood and steel decor.  And I can't forget the large collection of motorcycles arrayed throughout and the built-in shelves housing rows and rows of colorful homemade jams.About the jam:  the not-so-secret sauce in the most heavenly breakfast sandwich ever.  Start with a large and fluffy homemade buttermilk biscuit, layer on some killer sliced ham from the undoubtedly artisanal butcher shop next door, next for the cheese, and finally a thick smear of strawberry jam.  Insanely delicious...and there are a few others to choose from.  For a less carb-intensive complement, we also devoured a superb plate of soft scrambled eggs and homemade (maybe by the same butcher?) sausage.  Although they may start roasting their own coffee in the future, Barista Parlor has an intriguing and sensible approach, "hosting" about 8-10 awesome coffee "brands" which are VERY slowly "brewed" using one variety of pour-over method or another.  About the only thing I could find to criticize about this place is their lack of house-branded coffee mugs, but I'll be checking back for those in the future.

reviews.name: Danica L.
reviews.review: 1. Very pretentious. Felt out of place when I had to ask questions about the menu.2. Eventually was bullied on social media by one of the baristas. Not cool. (PSA: the motorcycles are not decorations. Don't touch them.)3. Coffee was decent. Crema was better by far, both in taste and in service.

reviews.name: Carmen P.
reviews.review: this shall from hence forth be known as the "sensitive lumberjack" coffee shop. the wait is incredibly long--just to order. the coffees and lattes are good, but not worth standing in line with 8000 other people for. they had macarons though! and those, those are awesome! i would totally wait in a line of 100000 (wait, that's too many "0's"... 1000) for their macarons. so, if you like being around really cool people, or sensitive lumberjack looking dudes who make coffee and lattes with designs in the top, then this is your place!

reviews.name: Karri B.
reviews.review: We have lived in East Nashville for five years and we were so happy when this place opened up. Hipster?  yesTrendy? yesAmazing? yesI know it's super hipster, but they make a damn good cup of coffee and the sausage biscuit is to die for.  Go there and have a good time and make sure to not take yourself too seriously!

reviews.name: Jon N.
reviews.review: Not sure why the bad reviews. How much cooler can it be to have a great pourover in an old garage? Great choices of coffee from top notch roasters. I had a sausage biscuit along with my coffee which was very good.My only deal is it's a bit pricey. Other than that the coffee was amazing! I can see why my friends recommended that I check it out!

reviews.name: Eryn P.
reviews.review: I hadn't been back to Nashville in three years, and have heard a million and one things about this lovely little spot.  Tucked in just below my church's offices, it's like it was always meant to be there. I mean, I don't even know what to say. It's kind of perfect, really. The most fantastic ambience for a coffee shop - the right amount of hipster, with the right amount of class. Perfectly casual but the greatest place to sit and work, or catch up with friends. Coffee is amazing. Had a cold brew that hit the spot perfectly.  I didn't get anything to eat but the guys next to me had sausage biscuits and I almost died in envy.  Next time for sure.Oh Nashville, you always catch my heart all over again. This was the icing on the cake this time.

reviews.name: nathan g.
reviews.review: Pretty ok

reviews.name: Jacky L.
reviews.review: Pretty cool spot..ex-warehouse type of place so it's huge and there's plenty of spots to sit at.  The line gets long since this is the 'coolest' coffee shop in the gentrified East Nashville.  A few reasons this gets a 3-star review (closer to 2.5 stars) and not any more.  But first, I'll say that the coffee here is pretty good and what everyone is saying about the biscuit (e.g., "It's amazing," "Absolutely delicious," "The quickest way to mess up your heart," etc.) is true, BUT, and this is a big one (no pun intended), that doesn't excuse you from piss poor service.  And yes, before any one jumps on this and says "but they're HIPSTERS!" - that may be true, but there's a line where it's cute and chic and where it's just stupid.  I'm from San Francisco, so I thought I've seen it all, but some of the stuff I've seen here is why I chose Crema over BP.  Anyways, a few of my gripes: no call-in orders..even if you're on the way (5-10 mins), patronizing manner in which you tell customers where the sugar and creamer is (e.g, "If you feel that you must add...they're over there in the corner." - this one didn't even happen to me, it was said to a poor fella in front of me), and taking absolutely forever to get me some biscuits..which is funny because they're getting the meat from PRB, which I'll get to later.I'll end it here saying that it's definitely worth checking out if you're visiting Nashville or just haven't been at BP before, but if you're looking for a few "go to's," I'd choose Crema for the coffee and if you want their breakfast biscuit, get it straight from the source at Porter Road Butcher (West).

reviews.name: Katie W.
reviews.review: The two stars are for the look of the place - very unique, clean, and, well, hip. Also a mean cold brew. However, two stars is generous given the food and prices. $8 for an egg & cheese biscuit that was barely decent and left us unsatisfied. Not to mention the fact that they were out of a bread (brioche) that consequently negated all of the lunch sandwich making abilities (no substitutions?), and the fact that a barista scoffed at my friend's request for any condiments to help make her sandwich more interesting. Despite awesome reviews from other people, I'm sorry to say I wouldn't go back. Though the beard game of all the gentlemen in the place was  on point.

reviews.name: Ivy T.
reviews.review: Impressive!!! Love everything about this coffee house. I love the ambiance and the vibe. Their coffee is on point and the baristas are very helpful and even answered my question about a very odd bit cool looking coffee maker. I got a cappuccino and it's coffeelicious! I was only visiting but I came back twice same day.

reviews.name: Shafi K.
reviews.review: This is a great little coffee shop in East Nashville. The atmosphere is super hipster with the bikes in the front, the mason jars, the funky looking table top decor and intense menu that is slightly overpriced. They do make some amazing coffee but honestly, I am not all about that $6 cup life. If you're looking for a quite place to work though, this is a better option than many places in East Nashville simply because it does not get too crowded during the weekdays. They have a lot of different outlets and seating arrangements. I saw many folks obsess over their biscuit. I did not have one because by the time I was a little hungry, their kitchen closed. Oh well-- now I know for next time. The cashier was super nice and tried to help out when I looked very confused at their menu, table arrangement and in-general set-up. :)

reviews.name: Sam S.
reviews.review: Stopped at this spot while visiting Nashville. Very cool atmosphere. I paid almost $7 for one of the best espressos I've ever had--the iced whiskey caramel espresso. Well worth the money. I suggest you check this place out if you're in town.

reviews.name: Kayla P.
reviews.review: Definitely the most unique coffee shop I've ever been to. In the heart of East Nashville, which has become known as the hipsterish part of town, you can come here to this garage to get served quality fair-trade coffee by trendy, bearded, apron-donning baristas while an indie record plays in the background (and you can actually go look at the turntable and selection of records they have.)Batista Parlor is a coffee shop that seems like it's meant to cater to people who love coffee in its purest form, so if you're seeking a big selection of lattes or frappes, Barista might not be the right place for you (although they do have a nice selection of lattes). When you order a cup of coffee there, you actually have to choose a blend and there'll be a description of the flavor profile and notes (my favorite I've tried is the Counter Culture blend.) Since all of the coffee is fair-trade and the brews are strong and high-quality, it is a little pricey. But, you definitely get what you pay for. Also, being located in such a hip area, it is (of course) vegan friendly, so you can substitute almond milk or buy a nice artisan dark chocolate to munch on.

reviews.name: Jeremy W.
reviews.review: Pricey but worth it! Great experience: solid food, well cared for and prepared coffee and espresso (and tea), friendly staff, location used to be a transmission shop I believe, very hipster, vintage vinyl i.e. no internet radio here, only vinyl! It will take more time than you may be used to to get your coffee/espresso drink but that's only because they take the time to do it right. Make sure you order up front before sitting and also know that seating is somewhat limited in winter so be sure to eye a place before deciding to stay. I was very impressed and will definitely return!

reviews.name: danielle m.
reviews.review: So very, very hipster and VERY expensive (e.g. $5 for cold brew, $7 for iced latte). But quality drinks and food, staff is very nice. Def not an 'everyday' kind of place though.

reviews.name: Yitzie B.
reviews.review: If you actually call yourself a hipster, this place is for you.If you specifically fashion your dress and beard based on the hipster aesthetic, this place is for you.If you just want to drink brand-name coffee for the sake of feeling like a hipster, this place is for you.I drink lots of coffee and I know hipster coffee quite well considering I spend most of my leisure time in Park Slope, Brooklyn: hipster capital of the world, for sure.To not be able to order an Americano, and, when denied that, to then again be denied the request to simply make me an espresso with hot water in it (an Americano), is simply pathetic.This place actually prides themselves as a "Barista centric coffee parlor" with all the tables facing the middle. Here, the barista is the rockstar, the customer is the lucky spectator.I ordered one of their brand name drip coffees. It was weak and not piping hot. I make myself drip coffee at my desk every morning and no matter how little beans I put in there, it comes out way stronger and hotter.If frequent many coffee "parlors" and I can assure you that it is totally unnecessary to have one each of completely separate brands of coffee to offer when most of these companies make all the different types of beans themselves, making it unnecessary to have a list of brands of coffee - over having a list of types of coffee.For example, Gorilla Coffee themselves make all the types of coffee you need to run a coffee shop. Same goes with Stumptown and the rest of the hipster coffee brands. So, the novelty of having different brands doesn't make it a more novel coffee shop. It just makes it childish.This place thinks it's hipster.The whole East Nashville is pretty much try-hard uber-hipster central.

reviews.name: Robert D.
reviews.review: Fantastic coffee, amazing atmosphere, knowledgeable staff, makes this please leaps and bounds better than any of the coffee shop we've been to. We cannot wait  to return for more coffee and breakfast.

reviews.name: Jolly M.
reviews.review: Superb review to follow!!!!! I love this place!!! I've never experienced anything like it. My first real coffee shop outside of the chain places.

reviews.name: Tessa J.
reviews.review: Trendiest coffee shop in town. The whiskey caramel is delicious but the mocha is actually pretty fucking gross. (I didn't know they use dark chocolate) I hated it so I ordered something else and they gave it to me for free because I didn't like the other one! Very nice people

reviews.name: golriz l.
reviews.review: I was here two years ago - pregnant and only drinking decaf and they don't offer that as an option. In fact they sneered when I asked for it as if it was an absurd request. Charming.On a recent visit, after asking the barista for recommendations we spent over $60 on coffee beans and were hugely disappointed with the flavor - not full bodied or round, instead the taste was super acidic and bitter :(It also took the staff forever to make two espressos. All in all, a lot of money spent and a poor taste left in our mouths.

reviews.name: Adrianna W.
reviews.review: Great atmosphere, great great coffee, clean simple food. Great place to experience the local vibe and cuisine.

reviews.name: Megan K.
reviews.review: Hip, eclectic and urban retreat for a cup of coffee. Don't expect to bounce in and out, a la Starbucks. This place is meant to attract the java fans who want to sit and stay a while. Their menu boasts an incredible mix of roasts and their breakfast items are savory. I can't recommend enough that you try the sausage biscuit with peach jam. Amazing. The central display of the place is a setup of beakers and tubes where coffee is rolling and dripping whimsically to and fro. I was watching it do its thing forever. Lots of store/local swag for sale (mugs, tumblers, chocolate and coffee). I absolutely recommend coming by and enjoying this place as soon as you can!

reviews.name: Christa K.
reviews.review: My first trip to Nashville and Barista Parlor was the first spot our friends took us. I ABSOLUTELY ADORE THIS PLACE.More businesses need to run like BP. They put so much thought and effort into everything  - food, coffee, decor, merchandise - it all is very high quality and all details are thought of. Their napkins are vintage handkerchiefs, their biscuits are served on hand made wood trays, and their coffee ---- OHHHH THEIR COFFEE! Its amazing. That is all. Get the biscuit with sausage and orange marmalade (and a Mast Brothers chocolate bar for the drive home).

reviews.name: Justin J.
reviews.review: If you want to drink coffee in a hip atmosphere, this place is for you. The staff is on point with excellent customer service. Very cool atmosphere. If your afraid of hipsters, don't choose this shop, they seem to run this place. My normal drink of choice is an iced Americano, which they did not normally make. They recommended there cold brew. Best cup of coffee I've ever had!! Some awesome coffee, but the only downfall for some will be the lack of diversity.Overall a must try for anyone in Nashville

reviews.name: Jimmy L.
reviews.review: So, visiting from outta town, and I had gone to the location at The Gulch first. Here is my Yelp review for that other location - yelp.com/biz/barista-par…After reading the Yelp reviews, I was curious as to how this one was gonna compare, and even though I know that's a matter of preference amongst people, I liked the vibe here better. Though hipster like the Golden Sound location, and similar in that the space is converted from a mechanic shop, this one had a slightly more of an edgy feel to it - and is a true reflection of the neighborhood it's in - as with the Golden Sound location.I read some of the reviews here with regards to the customer service, and I can actually see why this might be the case. With all due respect, the guys behind the counter here seemed more straight and narrow, and to-the-point, and perhaps exude a different kind of vibe -  but not in a mal-intentional kind of way. This actually is what made this place work better for me more than the other location, and I really liked the rough-around-the-edges feel to this place.I ordered the same items also - Moto Biscuit (egg and cheese) - I made them add extra white cheddar cheese, and also asked them to slather some apple butter on it. This made all the difference over the one at Golden Sound.Unfortunately, their espresso machine was broken, so I couldn't have the Bourbon Barrel Vanilla Latte that I wanted. :-( This was the biggest bummer, so even though I liked this location MORE than the Golden Sound, I'm gonna have to bump them down a notch. I ordered regular drip coffee, and it was just OK for me. For the sheer volume of coffee drinks, and the size of the place, I'm really surprised that they only have one espresso machine to rely on.

reviews.name: Sarah M.
reviews.review: Barista Parlor is a lot of things.... Fast is not one of them.I would imagine that they are making a fair amount of money when a cup of black coffee and bacon biscuit are around $13. So why on earth are they still using a post-it note system for all food and drinks?!?!? This is why the line is long, the girl at the front takes your food and drink order, then walks the post-it back to the kitchen and then over to the staff making drinks.... this happens each time someone orders! This is why the wait in line can be upwards of 30 mins. They really need to invest in restaurant software in order to speed things up (at least within the the kitchen)I arrived this past Saturday at 9 am and proceeded to wait in line for about 20 mins. I would have left had my friend not already ordered and had a seat at the table. Yes, the coffee is good and yes the food was good. However, I don't think it was worth the wait in line or wait at the table. I was almost done with my coffee before my biscuit came out. As my friend and I chatted, we have been there together multiple times, we decided that we needed to start going elsewhere as it has "been discovered" and isn't as quaint as it used to be. (Yes, we have turned into locals)  Like I said the food is good and the coffee is great.... I'm just not willing to wait 30 mins standing in line.

reviews.name: Andrew M.
reviews.review: What happened to customer service?! The employees are kind of a-holes and they over do the hipster thing. The coffee I had was way too acidic but the sausage biscuit was on point though. The wait was a joke and the prices are kind of high but I suspect that it's because they're trying to pay the rent and get back the investment they put in. A word of advice to owner and staff: If someone wants to order a typical coffeehouse drink (americano), they shouldn't feel uncomfortable doing so. Get over yourselves already. And be nice! Yes, we get that you guys are  wearing the hipster uniform but that doesn't mean you gotta be douches.

reviews.name: Anna J.
reviews.review: I think that I'm not hipster enough to appreciate this place. LOL.  They do not roast their coffee beans apparently, and really want the raw coffee bean flavor to come through... however, I was not a big fan of the "earthier" taste. I like my beans roasted... dark roast especially. I guess your enjoyment of the beverages here depend on your preference for coffee.  I am just not that sophisticated.  It was also the priciest coffee shop I've been to. They serve food (small snacks types) as well.  I didn't get to try any, but they looked good, especially the waffles.

reviews.name: Ruthie W.
reviews.review: I absolutely love place. When you enter, expect that you'll walk into a memorable, unique experience. The vinyl record player and speakers flood the wide open industrial room and brown stained concrete floor with americana, folk, jazz and alternative music. The room's furniture and decor is filled with clean lines in brown, grey, and dusty light blues. Nothing is out of place and everything is clean. The outside of the building shouts boldly with its bright blue and red paint. On a pretty day, you'll arrive to four fully open garage doors and two old motorcycles near the entrance. The coffee is top notch and the homemade biscuit sandwiches are out of this world, maybe even the best in Nashville!Don't come when you're looking for a quaint, dainty, and quiet coffee shop. The line can get a bit long. That's why you should come when you want to sit for a little while, not when you're expecting to grab a cup of coffee and run. Still, it's not overly loud, and if you can concentrate with some music and talking around you, you'll be fine when reading a book, doing some work on your computer, and especially catching up with a friend.

reviews.name: Meschelle H.
reviews.review: I absolutely LOVED this place!!While visiting my people in Tennessee, my bff took me around Nashville to see the sights.  We needed some liquid motivation, so we headed over to Barista Parlor.  First off, the space is beautiful.  Big garage doors, concrete floors, fun picnic tables to sit and sip on, local wares to purchase line the walls.  My favorite (besides the Japanese cold brew!) was the music.  Instead of having some ipod or whatnot they had a lovely record player hooked up and they were playing Willie Nelson and other great jams.  The counter is nestled in the middle of this joint, and they had a lovely selection of artisan chocolates and baked goods and coffee/teas, of course.  The Japanese cold brew (if you've never experienced it, you are seriously missing out!) was velvety smooth and delicious.  Drinks were all served in mason jars, which I think is just keen.  I even made a new Yelp friend there, Tron D.  Keep it real, keep it real good.

reviews.name: Liz N.
reviews.review: I can't believe this place is only 3 1/2 stars. People seem to be put off by a "hipster" environment (I think that word has lost it's meaning)  I found this place warm, cozy, and beautifully handsome. Every single person working here that we came in contact with was so incredibly friendly and welcoming. I had the bourbon vanilla specialty drink and it was perfect. My boyfriend had a stumptown pour over coffee and loved it. We both had different biscuit sandwiches and they were DELICIOUS!!  If you love unique places and enjoy a carefully crafted cup of coffee this is the place for you. Yes it's on the pricey side but you know what you're getting when you come to place like this, if that's not your thing then go to Dunkin' donuts. If I lived here I would probably come here everyday!

reviews.name: Andy B.
reviews.review: Good God I wish I could write two reviews for this place - one as a delicious coffee place, and one for the place that just served me one of the worst burgers I've ever paid for. I went for the two star rating, though, because of the number of flies that landed on my food, coffee, phone, and hands as I'm writing this. I had a delicious cup of Kenyan coffee. It was wonderful. The Kenyan touch of having flies bombard my coffee mug was not. Maybe I'll order from a less buggy region next time. The BURGER OF SHAME. Bacon and ground beef together should be wonderful. Can I have that med rare please? No, we cook them in the oven, so they are med well. Fine. I'll give it a go. I don't think they seasoned it at all. It was just this dry, dark gray patty, that sucked the lifeblood out of the rest of it. Seriously. I got to the end of the tiny burger and had some bun, tomato, and spicy mustard still to go, and that was quite delicious. Something's gotta change. You can't blame prb, the wonderful butcher shop next door for that burger having no flavor. Have em come over and show you guys how to cook one.

reviews.name: Ju L.
reviews.review: So unbearably hipster. And that's coming from someone who spends a not-insignificant amount of time in gentrified and gentrifying Brooklyn. If the staff knows their coffee, they don't know their tea. Teas are in bins on the wall. I was told that everything on top is decaf, everything below is caffeinated. When I asked the barista what his favorite one was, he said it was a green tea in one of the top canisters. Decaf green? Hmm. But when I retrieved it and finally got the cup, it was very clearly rooibos. Pft, "green tea."It was very muggy out and I asked if I could have the tea iced, but was told they didn't have the "capability." Me: "Can you brew it using very little hot water, and then add a ton of ice cubes that will melt?" The guy, while friendly, didn't seem to understand what I was saying, which was confusing in itself. He ended up giving me the regular hot tea with a separate cup of ice, so something was a little lost in translation.The rest is regular aesthetic over function... but it's neither sleek, nor unique, nor sincere-feeling. There are no menus up and no prices listed. The setup is such that a non-enclosed area in the center of the room is the staff's "behind the counter" space - not so clear at first glance and you might accidentally walk into it. Other gestures:- A tiki-like computer bar outside with lots of mac users- Large selection of "artisanal" chocolates "handcrafted" in Williamsburg or Portland. Who can resist great packaging though?Worth a visit as a tourist? If you're from a major city already, nah; you've seen this before.

reviews.name: Owen R.
reviews.review: Over rated. Completely confusing for anyone foreign/new.   $9 for two coffees, too expensive and long wait even at off times.  Guy with BOB haircut not friendly at all...  Silly large wooden sign for table recognition, bongo Java down the street is better and cheaper. Coffee wasn't even that good.

reviews.name: Daryl P.
reviews.review: I would love to give this place 5-stars, but there is just no way. I've given it several tries, but I just can't bring myself to ever go back. Pros- The space is awesome and the coffee is yummy. Cons- It takes F O R E V E R to get anything even if you're the only customer waiting, it's super expensive, they're pretentious and refuse to serve drinks that they've decided aren't good enough (like americanos or espresso over ice). Basically, the coffee better be spectacular if I'm gonna put up with all this other business. And it just isn't.

reviews.name: Dew T.
reviews.review: Super cool, trendy, and hip atmosphere. Stupid high prices ($4 for a 12oz tea). Paying for the experience for sure. I won't be back because the wait to make my team took 15 minutes and there was no one in line before me. 15 minutes to make a cup of tea is ridiculous.

reviews.name: Valerie F.
reviews.review: Everything here is right on point! There is so much care put into every detail of this place! From the branding- done by Isle Of Printing- to the decor & displays, to the staff, and, of course, to the food & drink- this refurbished mechanic shop, turned third wave multi-roaster, has everything a creative, coffee/food-lover could want. If I were local to Nashville, this would certainly be my home away from home!I stopped in twice the past couple days and took recommendations from baristas each visit:Day 1- Brock recommended the Oddly Correct Ethiopian Espresso & the Iced Bourbon Barrel Vanilla Latte (which I had w/ Almond Milk). _The Espresso is served w/ sparkling water & a house-made salted caramel- what a treat! A perfectly balanced presentation & an expertly-pulled extraction. _The Iced Bourbon Vanilla Latte is served perfectly sweet w/ proper, large ice cubes that ensure the integrity of the beverage for a good, long while! Day 2- Evan recommended the Verve Kenyan espresso & I ordered the Southern Frenchman sandwich on a GLUTEN-FREE biscuit- HALLELU! _The Southern Frenchman is a sweet/savory sandwich of egg, ham, swiss, paprika, & strawberry jam served on a perfectly executed gluten-free biscuit. In fact, if no one had told me that it was gluten-free, I would've had no idea! Between the friendly, knowledgable staff, the inspiring atmosphere & the incredible care & creativity put into all that they serve here, you can't help but leave refreshed & ready for your day! All in all, Great People Great Product Great Price Do yourself a favor, Nashville- get out to the Eastside & fuel up at Barista Parlor. You won't regret it! *NOTE- when I say "Great Price"- I mean that it is worth what they charge. Quality ingredients made by expert hands= worth it!

reviews.name: Brett S.
reviews.review: The coffee is good, but this place is absurd.  Waiting 15 minutes while the coffee chemists conduct their scientific process of making a $6 cup of coffee is just over the top.  "Too much" is a statement that applies to just about everything here.

reviews.name: Mindy W.
reviews.review: This is not a biased or emotional review. This place is esthetically beautiful inside and the pastries are quite gorgeous, themselves. I wanted this to be my new staple coffee shop. I've visited this location and the Golden Sound location 5 times now. Every time has been a let down. The coffee at Barista Parlor is simply not good. They brew too thin and use bitter beans. The employees are incredibly rude. Besides the many other negative reviews I've heard about Barista, a close friend had a very rude interaction with the manager, who asked her to never order her drink there again--because she asked for a little bit of almond milk in her coffee. I actually asked for non-dairy milk in my coffee the last time I went. I was laughed at, and obviously annoyed the employee, because he watched me pour it into the cup while shaking his head. So heads up: Don't ask for milk with your coffee--you'll be scowled at! Not to mention, $4-5 for a simple coffee? It better have magic in it, or make me fly, or contain gold, or do something extraordinary. Alas, it doesn't. It's a bitter coffee on a cool plank. Go to Frothy Monkey or Bongo instead.

reviews.name: Chris A.
reviews.review: Where do I begin with this one? :)I am a coffee fiend. I need coffee to function. There's lots of good and theres some bad involved with Barista Parlor. I will try my best to explain:The good: The coffee is absolutely delicious. Cold brewed techniques! Everything I have ate and drank here is great! I had a sausage biscuit sandwich with peach jam that melted in my mouth. And the coffee always feels good leeching in to my veins! Ok that was weird - but you know what I mean. The decor is awesome too. I love what they've done to the space. The bad: There is no visible menu until you get to the front where you order, so the problem with that is, you are forced to wait in line looking at the 100's of chocolates that they make from various ingredients (including wood! No I am not joking) that range in price from 6-8$ per chocolate bar. By the time you get to the front where you place your order, you then have the opportunity to look at the menu. So you of course, hold up the line yourself. Bad, and poor design. You wait. And wait, and wait. Hopefully you aren't in a hurry or planning on getting to work any time soon. The cost: A regular cup of coffee (not a prepared coffee, but just a coffee -that also takes just as long to make - costs 5$. The sausage biscuit costs 5$ I understand you can go to Carl's Jr. and get a 3$ sausage biscuit and the ingredients are going to be very poor quality. The quality of these is way better. And I still think its worth the price. Unfortunately I cannot really afford to come here as much as I want to. The good outweighs the bad in this case. I will continue to return here and support them. They share a passion in coffee.

reviews.name: Aaron A.
reviews.review: We stumbled on this coffee gem on our last day touring around Nashville.  Let me say that I am a huge coffee fan and have no problem admitting that I am a coffee snob.  We came here on a late weekday morning and had an easy time parking.  We walked up to the ordering station and was given a menu.  At first I was a little bit overwhelmed on how many coffees they had.  We were told that they brew each cup of coffee to order.  I don't remember which coffee I actually ordered but it was awesome!  We also ordered a latte for my wife which she really enjoyed.  We shared a breakfast biscuit as well.  The meat was great, but the biscuit was a little dry, seemed like a microwave biscuit.Overall Barista Parlor is a hit.  If I lived in Nashville I would come here often.  There is plenty of room to hangout with people, as well as intimate space for you to study by yourself.  I would love to see what bands play here, as there is a stage outside.  We also loved the ordering system and the poster of a figurine they gave you as your number to order.

reviews.name: Kevin K.
reviews.review: This is a nice hipsterish coffee shop. More Apple products and beards than you can count .. Pretty good coffee and some cool unique speciality drinks. The decor inside is really cool with old motorcycles in the lobby and what seems like steampunk coffee makers behind the counter. Overall for the neighborhood you really can't beat it for the environment. But there are always cheaper places to find coffee.

reviews.name: Brittney K.
reviews.review: Breakfast was amazing and so was the coffee and service but......Magets in my $10 chocolate bar!!!! Obviously these are extremely old. I was really excited to give this to my boyfriend-thankfully he spotted these guys before diving in!

reviews.name: Ashley W.
reviews.review: Absolutely AMAZING!! Recommended to me by my step sister. Their biscuits are probably some of the best I've ever had. I forgot what mine was called but it had sausage and orange marmalade on it. SO GOOD. Great coffee drink too.. I think it was called Mocha Madness or something. A little pricey but if you can splurge, do so on an amazing breakfast you'll have!! My mom and I spent $63 (not including tip) but that was 2 meals, a couple of their decadent and rich cookies, and three of their awesome looking chocolate bars. We loved their different selection of chocolate and pastry items. Definitely very hipster, but was happy to see many people of all ages there, from as young as early 20's to probably mid 50's. The staff was super friendly and helped us find everything. The decor is very cool. Loved the wood tables. The only thing I didn't like was that the condiments, napkins, and silverware was not easy to find. Napkins and straws were at the register (weird place for that kind of stuff since they bring the food and drinks out to you) and then sugar, coffee stirs, and syrup are in a totally different place. Kinda confusing. Definitely recommend!!

reviews.name: Christa P.
reviews.review: I really like this place but it does has some flaws. The coffe, dont get me wrong, is very very good - but so are a lot (a lot- I mean Nashville has tons of coffee spots) good coffee places in Nashville. The prices are getting mildly out of control. An iced (cold brew) coffee is now $5.5 - thats a lot. I really think overall the prices reflect the vibe and you are paying for the atmosphere. It is an awesome place to hang out - if you are trendy and live in East Nash. My sister and I came here for a coffee sister date and we sat at the high bar chairs around the edges. They are mildly uncomfortable as you can't really lean back and doesn't promote talking since its hard to not bang your knees against each other when sitting on the bar thats so narrow. The other long tables on the floor are awesome though. They have amazing lattes - my favorite is the bourbon barrel vanilla- oh man. The caramel is also great. I also love their cute and well picked artisian chocolate selection in the front. For a nice, trendy place to hang out- come here.

reviews.name: Ashton M.
reviews.review: The wait in line was about 10 minutes, and it took about 25 minutes for me to receive my coffee.I understand, though, it's a gourmet coffee experience. The coffee and espresso was, in fact, phenomenal. I wanted to forget about the long wait and give this place 5 stars, but it was unfortunately very noticeable.So, if you feel a caffeine headache come on, go somewhere else to get your fix in before the headache gets full blown. If you're looking for a place to relax, enjoy REALLY good coffee, and bask in the cool ambience, this place is for you.

reviews.name: Meg T.
reviews.review: I really wanted to like this place. Is is beautiful and has a great atmosphere, but I waited over 30 minutes for a regular cup of coffee. Walnut tables and Edison lightbulbs can't make up for the fact that the employees are pretentious and SLOW. They have a good selection of coffee (Four barrels from SF is my favorite) but it is overpriced and just not worth it.

reviews.name: Tim P.
reviews.review: It's just the best of the best.  It ain't cheap!!! But, I love it.  The staff is good looking and very professional.  The biscuits are contest worthy.  And, if you're a coffee enthusiast and don't mind paying for it this is your spot.  It's a classic East Nashville experience and no telling what celebrities you'll see.  LOVE!!!

reviews.name: Kina L.
reviews.review: I have a corner in my kitchen filled with siphons, flasks, and scales that sometimes makes me wonder if my roommate is truly getting his money's worth from his biochemistry degree...but turns out the man just loves his coffee. And he sho knows it too. We decided to make the trek (all 10 mins of it) to East Nashville to see what all the hype over Barista Parlor was. I have heard that it's considered one of the best in the nation...but better then that, my fabulously awesome hair stylist had recommended I stop by that very same day. Location: Barista Parlor is tucked away in the back of a shopping strip with boutique (no) choices like Rainbow fashions. It is right next door to Groove and Porter Road Butcher so you can use those as landmarks. The parlor is fenced off and has an amazing home made stage that you can imagine would make for the best live shows. There is some patio seating but I would say minimal... Parking is an interesting situation since you sort of have to drive through past the stage to get to the back. When you walk inside the parlor/garage you get a definite urban chic feel. They have pendant style exposed lighting hanging from the ceilings with walls full of coffee and coffee accessories. They carry the Aeropress...and for true coffee lovers.. you know. Coffee: It certainly takes a while to get your coffee, but its worth it. They have certain drip times that they follow and their method makes for the purest tasting coffee. Or so I am told. I rock out to pumpkin spice keurig, so yeah. A cup of coffee is going to run you $4. But like a lot of places in Nashville, the price is worth the ambience. Of note, I was seriously confused where their menu was... they carry two at the register...which of note...also took me a second to find. There is an enormous selection of packaged roasts on sale. However, they do not list prices. I was curious and asked and turns out the coffees run typically $16-22. Which is pricey...but it really is high quality coffee. AND ALSO for you (me) Keurig drinkers. We did an experiment the other day by dissecting out a keurig cup, weighing the contents and then doing some simple math.... y'all we are paying almost $30 a lb for coffee! Mind. Blown.Tea: Carries Intelligentsia teaTables: SUPER cool selection. You can choose your long communal study station or split off into the 2 people hanging side tables. Music: It's definitely on the louder side. I would bring really good headphones. However, the music is pretty chill and I personally liked it. I really enjoyed my experience here and will definitely be back. It's not really ideal for studying given how loud the music is...and its not definitely a place to pick up your daily coffee given the price point. This is where you would go to catch up with a friend to discuss major issues affecting society/the environment today. Like fracking.  Or more importantly...why is Selena Gomez getting back together with J. Biebs??????

reviews.name: Ashley H.
reviews.review: The cheddar and egg bisquit was amazing! I tried my first pour over coffee and wasn't too impressed. It just taste like old black coffee that had been sitting in the pot a few hours. Great atmosphere, but the seating it kind of sucky. Large tables so you have to sit with strangers. Lots of open floor space that they should put smaller tables in. I also got a sea salt carmel chocolate ganash tart that was to die for! I'd go back!

reviews.name: Matt W.
reviews.review: The lack of stars baffles me. Cool vibe, wonderful decor and extremely friendly baristas. They never made me feel like my questions were stupid and made excellent suggestions. If I'm ever in Nashville I consider Barista Parlor a destination stop.

reviews.name: Leah V.
reviews.review: Saturday morning at 10:30am gets you a 45 minute wait to place your order, and an additional 30 minutes waiting for your order. Atmosphere is great and the Moto Biscuit is delicious but with the wait, it kind of defeated the purpose coming here... Might be going else where next weekend for our coffee. Also $18 for two biscuits and 1 coffee is a bit steep....

reviews.name: Matt C.
reviews.review: Went to Nashville for a few days to watch a show and relax a little bit. This place was great--from the food to the decor--absolutely no complaints at all. The vintage motorcycles were a perfect touch and the long tables with barrel stools were sweet. I will definitely be returning when I visit Nashville. This place is definitely recommended.

reviews.name: Hayley L.
reviews.review: The bourbon vanilla latte is a paradigm shifting experience. Not really, but it's really good coffee and you'll feel pretty cool for being a patron here, you hipster, you. Slightly overpriced, but I'm sure you'll manage. All the baristas look like lumberjacks and are ridiculously good looking. Give us common folk a chance, here. Go for a visit. You'll be happier with caffeine. It's scientifically proven.

reviews.name: Aaron A.
reviews.review: Honestly the only reason why I am rating this place 4 stars instead of 5 is because of the wait time to get good and coffee after it's ordered. I've been twice now and both times the wait has been exceptionally long. Now, with that being said, there's a reason why the line sometimes forms all the way out the door...and it's not to see the retro motorcycles that adorn the inside. The food (especially the biscuits) are fantastic! I love the Whisky Carmel Latte there as well. When friends come in town this is definitely a place I'll take them.

reviews.name: Phil E.
reviews.review: I visited here on my recent Nashville trip. Was told it was so  hip it hurts kind of place.  It is that, but the food delivers.  Food and coffee were both good.  The hipster vibe is a bit much, but didn't get in the way of good food.  I heard it can get crowded and long waits, I was there on a Thursday morning 9 am and there were about 5 people there, so not an issue for me.  I would definitely return on my next trip to Nashville.

reviews.name: tracy m.
reviews.review: This place reminds me of Lamill at home. I love it. The staff are really helpful, friendly, and patient people, and really they just want you to have an excellent coffee.  Last time I went I had a cappuccino.  It was excellent. Meanwhile, get the biscuit. It is literally the best biscuit I've ever had.  Have it with their sausage and jam. I want to say that everything is house-made. It is possible that your order will take a bit longer than you expect to get to you.  Try and be zen about it. It takes lots of work to made a quality drink, and those guys get super busy.  Hang out and enjoy the beautiful space.  If Evan is there, chat with him! That guy rules. I want to go to there. Right now.

reviews.name: Almond M.
reviews.review: Barista recently celebrated their 2 year anniversary. That's two years too long that this pretentious and highfaluting coffee shop has been open. Perhaps the mecca for hipsters, the concrete building is housed in a stereotypical, renovated garage lined with over-the-top motor bikes. Three-legged crooked wooden stools, cushion not included, are their sad excuse for seating. Vinyl records blare from jukebox speakers as ambitiously cool artists work away on their macbook pros. They're so engulfed, they hardly notice that every order of overpriced coffee takes 12 minutes. Or perhaps they do notice, but blindly believe the wait makes the coffee taste better. They are sadly deceived. And if you have the audacity to request your coffee extra hot, you'll be scorned upon and possibly escorted outside. After all, these baristas have Ph.Ds in coffee.

reviews.name: Tyler J.
reviews.review: Honestly.. best coffee/espresso in town without a doubt.It's definitely got an upscale hipster vibe, so be prepared for that. Don't come on a Saturday or Sunday morning unless you love waiting in line. I will admit though that the folks I've stood next to in line are awfully kind, and I've definitely made some friends there.Order a flat white with almond milk. Thank me later. The PRB Sausage Biscuit with egg is frickin' great.Only reason I'm giving four instead of five stars... it's super super trendy/hip, and the seats aren't particularly comfortable.Seriously though, it's worth checking out. Great place.

reviews.name: Zeb M.
reviews.review: I'm very much in the middle of the road about Barista. Are you a coffee snob? Do you LOVE coffee with a passion? Then you'll love Barista Parlor.Do you enjoy coffee like I do, drink it practically every day, but by the end of the day... it's still just a drink? Then you're better off at Ugly Mugs or Bongo Java down the road.Look, I can understand the concept of "artisan coffee," even paying $6 for it (sometimes), but in no way does it deserve a 5 star rating. What I don't understand, however, is how people swear by this place that it's "so amazing!!" Not for everyone. I can only take so much of their pretentious decor and attitude once in a blue moon.

reviews.name: Xander S.
reviews.review: I'm from Baltimore,  and first of all, there is nothing like this there. I've been following BP on instagram for a while and knew if I ever visited, I'd make sure to stop by. I got this chance a few months ago and it met every expectation I have in a great independent coffee shop. The atmosphere is old, rustic, nostalgic, American, and edgy (in a good way). The staff was well trained and knew what they're doing. They offered a variety of great roasts of espresso and coffees from solid roasters. Oh and their food was delicious too. I recall getting the sausage egg and cheese apple biscuit. The biscuit melted in my mouth and the sandwich was extremely filling. They're very experimental and semi pricy, but you can expect that coming from a top notch shop. Easily a top 10 best shops in the US. If you're in Nashville, do yourself a favor and go there whether it's for a date, ridin solo, or a group of friends catching up. I wish I lived closer, I'd be there all the time.

reviews.name: Don T.
reviews.review: Visiting Nashville from Columbus, OH. Always on the search for great, local offerings. Barista Parlor fits the bill with superb service, coffee, limited menu, and ambiance. The location is a bit obscure yet, on the fringe of the East Nashville/Five Points vicinity. BP is an example of what's fresh, local, and exciting in Nashville.

reviews.name: Karen M.
