reviews.review: Loved this place.  First time in Nashville in 3 years and this was the greatest find.  The guy at the airport mentioned this place and when I searched the best coffee in Nashville this cafe came up.  Tried the latte and chocolate scone yesterday and had to make a special trip to stop by this morning before heading to the airport.  The latte was very smooth (tried both almond milk and regular milk) and went so well with the chocolate. sconePlus their music is vinyl.  Very nice.

reviews.name: Erin M.
reviews.review: Such a find  however it is back behind a building so focus when coming down the street  indoor outdoor seating very open and just nice to sit and have coffee  food is good if u like a kick sausage is spicy  great bacon very nice staff first time we got southern hospitality

reviews.name: Kelly S.
reviews.review: DAMN good gluten free biscuits.  So good I went back for them again that day.  Awesome eggs, awesome sausage.  Even better with honey.  Though the cornbread paled in comparison.

reviews.name: Christie P.
reviews.review: Definitely hipster. Very slow to get coffee (we didn't get this delivered until we ate most of the food). Good atmosphere. Great bacon and food. Somewhat pricey for what you get.

reviews.name: Larry S.
reviews.review: Do you think overalls are awesome, but have never worked a day of manual labor in your life?Do you smugly look down upon people with ONLY ONE SLEEVE of tattoos? Do you talk about how awesome vintage motorcycles are but don't know how to change your oil?This place is for you!In terms of the coffee... fantastic. The barista's are knowledgeable and surprisingly friendly for how niche this crowd is. Don't come though if you are going to order a mocha-frappa-crapachino. They don't make Starbucks drinks here. Get the hell outta here with those.

reviews.name: Jason N.
reviews.review: Great selection of Coffees (and ways to have it brewed) and a really nice menu of breakfast items. This is a quintessential Nashville stop for people just visiting. The service here is outstanding, everyone is always very friendly.

reviews.name: Jacob A. T.
reviews.review: Great coffee. They have quality coffees anywhere from just esspressos to creative mixes like "The Shoeless Joe" which is esspresso, coke, cherry, lime, and ice.They also have some food and i'd say the breakfast items are the best.The hipster staff might be intimidating at first, but just ask them anything, and they'll help you out.Great enviromemt, and a lot of space for people. Free wifi!

reviews.name: Annette K.
reviews.review: My husband and I have been here twice, and we love it! Very cool atmosphere, friendly staff, and great drinks. Today was a beautiful day, so the garage doors were open which made it just as nice to sit inside as out on the patio. My husband always gets an espresso shot. They have a Slayer espresso machine, and they taste test their espresso every two hours to ensure quality. The staff is super helpful and patient (especially when it comes to someone like me who is not a coffee connoisseur). Cold brew is amazing! I got a cold brew bourbon vanilla latte. It was fantastic! I highly recommend the Barista Parlor if you are in the area.

reviews.name: Josua J.
reviews.review: I am a huge espresso fan and know it is hard to find good espresso outside of Italy. I traveled to Italy at least once a year and it is almost impossible to get a bad cup of espresso, but anywhere else in the world it can be pretty tough to get a good one, but, if you search hard enough you are mostly able to find at least one place in a city that is able to make it properly. Also I am a hobby barista and have a lot of experience with Italian portafilter machines. So I heard about BP as probably the best coffee / espresso spot in town and was excited to check it out. First of all I was impressed by the design of the place and it all looked super professional at the first sight and I loved to see, that they have the slayer espresso machine with which you can make amazing espresso. So far, so good. The prices where shocking, especially for the simple espresso. $4 dollars for a cup of espresso and just 50ct more for a cappuccino. Normally the espresso should be more like closer to half the price of a cappuccino. I don't mind to pay for good quality, but also my expectations where pretty high and since a filtered cup of coffee was the same price and looked like one of their signature drinks, I started with that first. I took the "handsome". It looked also professional how they made it, but when I tried it, it is was quite disappointing, because it was one of the most sour tasting coffees I ever had and didn't taste good to me at all and I couldn't keep drinking it. So I thought I have to try the pure espresso since they have the slayer machine also. I ordered one of the two espresso bean choices and when it came I was already disappointed by how the crema looked. The color was a little too dark, but more important there was not much crema at all and it was too thin. The taste was horrible, it was really one of the worst espresso experiences that I ever had. It was so sour that it almost hurt my throat. I went back to the counter and explained why I cannot enjoy the espresso and the gentleman offered me to do another one with the other type of beans. It looked the same and tasted even worse, more sour. I just had two sips and couldn't finish it. A female associate came by and asked, if everything is ok now and I explained that I am really disappointed with the taste and wanted to explain why. She interrupted me and tried to explain me that they use a different machine (slayer) and darker roasted (Italian style) coffee beans, which I already was aware of. She was not interested in what I wanted to say and just gave me a little toffee as an apology. They did not offer me a refund or anything similar. She gave me the feeling, that I don't know anything about good coffee and that I think the coffee tastes so bad, because I have a bad taste and never had good coffee in my life. It really offended me and all in all I am very disappointed and had one of the worst customer experiences ever. I will definitely never come back nor recommend that place to anybody.

reviews.name: Dan E.
reviews.review: I held out for a long time on Barista Parlor, but finally gave in recently.  My sister was visiting from out of town and I wanted her to see what a Nashville coffee shop looked like.  I'd heard so many people rave about the coffee, but had also heard you may wait a while.  Well, despite that knowledge I was completely unprepared for the wait.Upon our arrival, we took our places in the back of the line.  The line was probably 20 people at that point.  And we waited.  We talked and conversed and observed the hippest of all hipsters.  And we waited some more.  All while wondering where in the world the menus were and what was in the advertised drink of the day.  And we waited.  And where is that menu?We finally found out that there are only two menus.  One at the register and one that is passed back in the line.  But when someone holds onto that menu, you don't see if for a long time.  Which makes it a little difficult to know what in the world you're ordering.After at least 30 minutes in line, we finally reached the register.  We ordered drinks, bought an unpriced chocolate bar that turned out to be $8, and proceeded to wander in search of two seats (which was rather difficult given the large amount of open space and limited number of actual places to sit).  The space is great if you're just talking aesthetics, but it's not very functional or efficient.  Once we sat down, we waited some more.  And then some more.  With only a simple coffee and a hot chocolate, we didn't anticipate that it would take terribly long.  But it was another 15 or so minutes before our drinks finally came out.I can't say that we had a terrible experience with any of the baristas or staff (perhaps we didn't ask enough questions to get glares and rude responses), but they also were not overtly friendly.As for the drinks, I'll start with the good.  My sister seemed to really enjoy her coffee.  So at least given all of the waiting, they had created a decent product.  I think the coffee would probably get 4 stars.  My hot chocolate, however, was honestly one of the worst I've ever had.  I'm not certain there was chocolate in it.  My sister tasted it thinking I was crazy given that it was Olive and Sinclair, a very expensive and fancy hot chocolate.  She confirmed.  You could hardly taste cocoa.  Or sugar.  I actually ended up adding pieces of the chocolate bar we purchased as well as sugar to it on my own just to make it taste like something.  I would prefer gas station hot chocolate, or even lowly Swiss Miss, to what I had there.Maybe it was a bad day.  Maybe they just screwed up the drink.  But the wait of at least 45 minutes seems normal or even short for this place.  And that kind of wait for a sub-par product is certainly not worth it.  Is it trendy?  Sure.  But to me it seems like another place that hipsters go just to say they go there.  It's a place to see and be seen, a place to talk about, and a place to Instagram for likes.On the other hand, the biscuit sandwich DID look really good...but I would never pay that much for one.

reviews.name: Laura O.
reviews.review: Barista Parlor has a definite hipster vibe, but ironically I found the Gulch location to be less so, and the service there was friendlier albeit slow.  It really wasn't that busy at the time.I was with some latte drinkers so I joined them for a whiskey caramel, which I found to be better than the bourbon vanilla someone ordered that was way too sweet.  We ordered homemade pop tarts, biscuits, and macaroons.  All were great.  Overall I prefer the coffee at Crema.

reviews.name: Diana K.
reviews.review: I'm sorry, but my visit here was a disaster. We paid $10 for two simple iced coffees. They took nearly 15 minutes to make, had barely any options of creamers or sweeteners, and the coffee tasted extremely watered down. I'm not sure if it was an off day, but visitors seemed to be enjoying the cool decor and atmosphere of this place. I couldn't drink my coffee and had to trash it - I am definitely not cool enough for this place!

reviews.name: W P.
reviews.review: Visiting from Seattle and we were itching for a decent cup of coffee... If you're into the intricacies and subtleties of good coffee, this is a fine place. Cool decor (the cable-suspended wall tables caught my 'design nerd' eye), suitably friendly staff, and most important of all a well-brewed cup of coffee. The Bourbon Vanilla latte that I tried was also very good. Some might say it's a "hipster" or coffee snob joint, but it didn't feel pretentious. And the pricing was very reasonable considering what some people pay for a starbucks specialty drink. Don't over-think it...if you want good coffee in a creative, youthful place, this is the spot.

reviews.name: Alexander L.
reviews.review: Came here for morning coffee and something to eat at around 8:30 AM on a Saturday in July. Short line (for me) that quickly extended 15-20 people deep by 9:15AM or so. My rundown:Pros:-Great coffee selection. Wide variery of roasts with flavor profiles listed below each option. You can also choose the way that you would like it brewed. V60 (basic brew method) generally starts at $4, which is fairly priced considering nothing is pre-brewed. I got the Stumptown. Was perfectly brewed!-Peach Waffle was a great choice. Perfect amount of syrup served along with the waffle. Menu looked like it had plenty of other great eats-Ambiance was what blew my mind the most. The little pixelated mosaic on the back wall really helped brighten up the space. Very wide open setup that did not make you feel like someone was breathing over your shoulder/reading your morning Reddit feed.-Huge selection of coffee beans and brewing aparatuses. I've never seen bags of coffee this big. If Amazon were to ever implode, would definitely come here to buy a backup Chemex and replenish the pre-apocalyptic bean reserve.Cons:-Took a little while to get my food. I was second in line upon walking in and guessed another 4 people were ahead of me for food. By the time the Waffle arrived, I had finished my coffee because it was getting cold. Not a huge con since this was the first cup of the day.-Only received a fork with the utencil set. Would have been nice to get a knife as well to cut the waffle and peaches. I sent a peach flying across the plate after trying to cut it with a knife. Not sure if there were knives elsewhere in the shop.-Slanted mini barstools surrounding the coffee bar were a tad uncomfortable. This could be understandable if the low bar had outlets and the stools were designed as a means to prevent Wifi squatters. No outlets though. Tl;dr: Great place to get an excellent cup of coffee and bite to eat in a creative environment. Would like a knife and some flat barstools at the awesome low-bar next time.

reviews.name: Jenna M.
reviews.review: We stopped here during a road trip. We are lucky enough to know one of the baristas, Robbie. He's great!! We fell in love with this coffee house immediately. Their attention to the little details was impeccable. Everything from the menu to the plates was unique and well thought out. The atmosphere was very relaxing. It was a wonderful stop that recharged us for the long drive ahead of us.

reviews.name: Brittany F.
reviews.review: Good quality coffee and food in a super cute atmosphere! Definitely a notch above some other local coffee shops and miles ahead of Starbucks!! My only complaint is that the menu is at the register.

reviews.name: Micheal P.
reviews.review: Hey! Are you looking for some coffee steeped in pretension? Have I got the place for you!Let's start with the obvious. You're not going to get your coffee quickly at this place. Though, a single glance at the long line of hipsters would have told you that. You'll probably spend about 20 min waiting to order. Maybe you can spend that time looking at a menu? Guess again, hotshot! Hipsters don't need menus! You'll find one, that's right, ONE, framed at the cash register. Even then, when you finally see the menu, none if it will make sense. There's a bunch of  v + number business that somehow refers to the method by which the coffee is freshly brewed. If you stare too long at the menu, the barista will doubt your authenticity, so just quickly order whatever the person in front of you had.When I say the barista will doubt your authenticity as a coffee drinker, what I mean is that this is inevitable so you should just prepare yourself to feel like an idiot. I ordered a cup of freshly brewed coffee and requested some almond milk to go with it. Do they have almond milk? Of course. Will they put it in your coffee? HELL NO. That might spoil the pure and heavenly black elixir that they have painstakingly brewed for your exclusive admiration. The barista eventually agreed to give me a cup of almond milk on the side, that I might add to my coffee, but only after making me promise, out loud, to taste the coffee without it. This really happened.Of course, after the 20 min in line, you'll spend 20 min waiting for your coffee and food, so your total minimum time in the barista parlor is 40 min, guaranteed. Food is upscale and good, though slightly overpriced. An acceptably tasty biscuit with fancy meats, etc. The coffee is obviously perfect. How could it not be? But you'll find it difficult to relax amidst the massive amount of douchery.The real product on display at this place is not the coffee, it's the baristas. The whole operation seems geared towards making you marvel at these hip baristas wearing their leather aprons and making coffee with their willy wonka coffee contraptions. Can you get a delicious cup of coffee at the barista parlor? Absolutely. But you're better off going to one of the many fine coffee establishments of Nashville and avoiding these asshats.It gets a four because I rate almost exclusively on taste, but I'm never going back.

reviews.name: Leonard C.
reviews.review: Neat place, hip and trendy. Expect to see beards and tats and ear gauges. But the coffee's good, pastries are tasty and interesting, and you can feel like a cool kid even when you're an old boring guy like myself.

reviews.name: J R.
reviews.review: Service is a bit long. My order was mixed up. I did enjoy the homeade sausage biscuit.  The inside looks interesting. It seems like a hipster spot. Nothing special.

reviews.name: Mai H.
reviews.review: It might not have the most original concept for a coffee shop like many reviewers noted, Barista Parlor still definitely deserves to be regarded as one of a few hidden gems of Nashville. Just one door away from another gem - No.308, Barista Parlor is truly a pleasant surprise on the very unlikely Gallatin Ave. Regardless of what some people had to say about this place, you can't deny that, 1- the place is super cool, 2- the baristas are skilled, hip and extremely friendly, 3- their drinks are good.I will definitely return heck yeah.

reviews.name: Paulo A.
reviews.review: Excellent spot! The baristas are really nice people and the food/coffee was great! Highly recommend it!!!

reviews.name: Ali G.
reviews.review: LIVES UP TO THE HYPE!After reading about this place on a list of best coffee shops in the USA I decided to give it a go while exploring East Nashville.It took me a minute (probably blinded by hunger and lack of caffeine) to find the spot as it is tucked away behind a women's consignment shop but once seeing it the sprawling outside area and garage doors opening up to the rustic (and yes "hip" interior) I was filled with excitement. The very nice red-bearded cashier directed me to try their limited edition brew they were serving along with the top -selling sausage and orange marmalade biscuit. I was very happy to not have to decide what I wanted and to have it be delicious!Once ordered, I ventured outside and after almost too long of a wait my coffee and breakfast arrived. The coffee was a bit bitter and tangy yet pleasant to drink black. It comes in a carafe to enjoy sips of coffee slowly. The biscuit was also spot-on, perfectly sweet and crumbly, savory savory sausage and marmalade I was licking off my finger. Great first meal in Nashville!

reviews.name: Kim I.
reviews.review: Was in town for the day and went here on the recommendation of some local friends. It is hipster to the max - take that for what you will - but they know what they are doing! The coffee drinks were good (got the vanilla bourbon latte and the BP soda pop), the atmosphere is fantastic for working or meeting friends, great music, and super friendly staff. The food looked good, but I settled on a biscuit with jam (homemade strawberry) and it was amazing! All in all a great place to pop in for breakfast or just a relaxing coffee. The only reason it's not a solid 5-star is because it is so darn hard to find, and street front signage is poor.

reviews.name: Lauren E.
reviews.review: Great space, amazing selection of coffee roasters- stumptown four barrel intelligentsia sightglass as well as specialty espresso drinks! Friendly staff and lots of space to do work or hang out with friends.

reviews.name: Jeanette H.
reviews.review: Best coffee in Nashville!  We spent most of our mornings here while visiting Nashville.  Friendly staff and stellar coffee selections.  Amazing GF macaroons.  Beautiful spacious open floor plan.  Great music as well!

reviews.name: T T.
reviews.review: 20 min wait for Espresso. That's AFTER ordering. The irony also seems lost on them too. Cortado comes Luke warm w way too much milk. Hipster bulls***t.Go to Crema.

reviews.name: Brian S.
reviews.review: I'm writing and posting this review from Barista Parlor, rather than actually doing work, because, like, work and stuff. Anyway, I'm really impressed.This places oozes of awesome ambience. From the garage doors to the mosaic tile to the aged wood to the baristas wearing early 20th century attire, the word to describe it is "neat." Even the lighting has that old-timer feel, which is a refreshing and relaxing change compared to the fluorescent or over-modernized incandescent stuff you see in most shops. In short, it's the kind of place you'd expect to find in East Nashville.As for my whiskey caramel iced coffee, the presentation matches the motif. Served in a Mason jar, I secretly wished that it might contain moonshine. No dice. The flavor was pretty good, although it took about 10 minutes to get it. I'd already eaten, else I would have scarfed down some of the pretty decent looking food I saw others eating. Well, probably not THEIR food, because that would be rude, but you get the idea.There are a few power outlets scattered around, and that seems to be enough for a slow day where at most a third of us are poking away on our laptops. It might be problematic if it were a busier afternoon.It's a pretty eclectic mix of people. You have your usual flannel-wearing East Nash hipsters, of course, but folks in dress slacks have come in too. And if you're wondering whether there are pretty people, the answer is yeah. Speaking of, to the guy next to me, Zach Morris called and wants his hair back.Areas to improve? First, as others have mentioned, parking's a bit rough. Despite it not being crowded, there was only one space left in the back. Also, the music should get cranked down a couple notches. Saying that probably makes me seem like an old guy who screams at kids to "get off my damn lawn," and indeed I'm probably on the older side here...but I'd have a hard time concentrating or even hearing a soft spoken person.Overall, awesome place.

reviews.name: Lindsay R.
reviews.review: Really wanted to love it, and what a let down. Love the anchor outside, but that's about it. Snotty staff right off the bat, seemed annoyed we had never been there before, one girl was amazing and was helping us out and this awful guy cut her off and jumped in and was so rude! The menu is confusing, the wait time is beyond ridiculous, I hate the stupid man wooden statue thingie you have to carry with you in place of an order number, music seemed kind of boring.....pretty interior, but that's about it. They seemed annoyed we asked for more cream (the container was empty!)....average coffee, only finished it because we paid so much for it! Really was curious to try the breakfast sandwich that everyone always talks about, but they had already stopped serving food for the day....lame. Bad hours.

reviews.name: Alyson M.
reviews.review: So I came here despite the reviews of how long it takes to get food etc. Hoping that on a Monday morning I wouldn't be fighting the masses so I'd be OK. I was partially right. This place is totally hopping however it took less than 10 minutes to get my food & drink. The cashier met me at the far end of the counter to give me a menu and was incredibly helpful when it came to both food and drink order. Whiskey caramel latte... perfection. Got it iced. It's on the sweeter side but I like sweet.  Biscuits and gravy are a little too spicy for my Minnesotan pallette but in all fairness I was duely warned.  Despite the spice the sausage has fantastic flavor and the biscuits are some of the best I've ever had!

reviews.name: Kessler N.
reviews.review: Best coffee, brunch, and atmosphere ever! I could stay in this place forever. They thought of everything to make it a great coffee experience. Even the menu is a creative genius. The food is local and made fresh. We ate the peach waffles (which were the best I've ever had), BLT, and sausage biscuits. Amazing!

reviews.name: E F.
reviews.review: Best coffee during my trip to Nashville!

reviews.name: Saya H.
reviews.review: Weirdly yet cooly tucked off of the street, off a little strip mall. At first I thought I was entering an industrial park. But then I saw the cool Barista Parlor sign and outdoor seating. And THEN, an outdoor stage! Only in Nashville. Very cool.It's one huge room, filled with beautiful lighting, people, and glassware. Took a really long time to order but I was so busy looking at everything, I didn't care. Had a sausage biscuit (YUM) and a latte.Great variety of seating.Loud music, which was actually ok for the most part as it drowned out the conversation of the people who were sharing a table with me. But when it turned into a song I didn't like, it bothered me. But good tunes were soon back on.Variety of lap-toppers, groups working on work, and pairs chatting.Friendly staff.My one complaint is that they don't have any non-coffee beverages (save for tea). I know, it's a coffeehouse. But I was dying for a juice or pop or the likeCool find!About an 8 min walk from a b-cycle dock, which was nice, as I biked from downtown and then enjoyed the short walk over.

reviews.name: Hilary D.
reviews.review: This place is really cool from the neat motorcycles to the old radios playing vinyl. Oh and the coffee is great too along with the selection of chocolates and pastries. My bf got the pop tart it was amazaballs.

reviews.name: Kristen H.
reviews.review: $6 plus tax and then they request a tip for a pour over. Lattes around the same thing. Pour overs are mainly little coffee, mostly water, didn't taste right from the few times I tried ti. Lattes are more milk than espresso, makes me wonder if there was much caffeine in it all. Plan on waiting 20-25 for anything when it's not busy or 30-45minutes when it is busy. Not to-go friendly due to the outrageous wait times. The only good thing I can give them now is how great their food is from pastries to breakfast, I'd eat it all if I could.

reviews.name: L B.
reviews.review: I'd heard and read good things about the place, so we went on Saturday morning for coffee and breakfast. First, I asked if there were menus, and a barista said there were a couple at the register. I asked at the register if we could look at one while in line, and was told no, these are the only two and you look at them when you're at the front. Waited in the long line, and when it was our turn, I asked what decaf coffee they had. You'd have thought I was asking for a soda or something. I asked why they didn't have any, and she informed me they had not found any that they felt were good enough. Interesting, since other higher-end places like 8th and Roast have. Plus good establishments like Fido (bongo java), frothy monkey, the Well, etc. Totally disappointed, I looked at the food menu. She asked if we needed a minute and she'd take someone else's order. Um, no, I waited on everyone in front of me to decide, so surely 60 seconds won't kill the process while you wait on me to pick something. All that said, our breakfast biscuits were amazingly good. I has the regular one with sausage and cheese, hubby with ham and raspberry jam. Really delicious. Based on food, I'd give it five stars. But with the vibe and lack of decaf, I'd give it one. Hence 3.All in all though, I won't return. I felt the service was too snooty, and I can get to multiple great places with great food, service, and decaf drinks in my own neighborhood (12S).

reviews.name: Emily T.
reviews.review: Decor is awesome, people are awesome, sweet treats are awesome, coffee is awesome. Enough said. Go visit them!

reviews.name: Jenifer G.
reviews.review: I love the design, as this is in a former garage space.  It's off the beaten path, for sure, tucked behind Rainbow Fashions on Gallatin.  The pluses for me are the atmosphere, the food (though a tad bit expensive since they use "local" ingredients like Benton's-which are in quotes on the menu for some reason), it doesn't smell like coffee (I don't drink it), the food prices are rounded to the whole dollar and it will take a lot for this place to feel crowded. The minuses for me, as a work-at-home gal who goes to places like this to pretend that I have co-workers, are the lack of outlets, few non-coffee drink choices, no high backed chairs near those precious outlets, and a dearth of Black people.  No, wait, there's another one!

reviews.name: Gary C.
reviews.review: Freshly shaven face when I walked in; full beard when I walked out. If you have even the slightest bit of impatience, turn away. Oh, but the pour-over coffee, sausage biscuits, and scone were fantastic.

reviews.name: Kenneth A.
reviews.review: It's unfortunate that this coffee shop is suffering bad reviews from people who don't know how to appreciate a place like this. Most of the negative reviews I'm reading are purely based on people not knowing the difference between Starbucks and a one-of-a-kind boutique coffee shop that serves incredibly high-quality coffee. You wouldn't dare go to a five-star restaurant and ask the chef to hold three ingredients and add two you prefer. You wouldn't complain about there being three forks and not knowing which to use. You certainly wouldn't complain about the portion sizes on a four course meal. Why? Because this isn't Golden Corral. You don't smother your french fries in a sea of ketchup and pay $9 for all you can eat ribs. That might be what you are used to, but that doesn't mean all restaraunts operate in that fashion. Barista Parlor is unique in that it's offering the best espresso/coffee beans from around the country. If you go to Stumptown in Seattle, you get their amazing roasters serving up their coffee. If you find yourself at Blue Bottle or Sightglass in San Francisco, it's the same high-caliber baristas pulling decadent shots and truly crafting your drink using their product. Barista Parlor stocks the best beans from all of these places and lays them out for your choosing. Ok, ok... I guess it is a little like Golden Corral... but more like if the best chefs in the world were preparing the food. None the less, people should expect to pay a little more for renowned espresso being pulled through a thirty-thousand dollar machine. You should pay a little more for craft and precision. It's not even that much more expensive. A cappuccino at Starbucks would run me $3.10. I payed a whopping $1 more at Barista Parlor for a cappucino that supremely destroys Starbucks. Which brings me to my last point...If you don't LOVE the taste of GREAT coffee. DO NOT COME HERE! If you are absolutely fine with the "Super Dark Roast Arabica Robusto Blend" they serve at Thornton's gas stations, then you should totally go save some money and get your caffeine fix. However, if you want to taste coffee in ways you've never imagined, using methods you've likely never seen, in an environment that's truly it's own... you MUST visit this place!  I've traveled all over the country to some of the best coffee shops, and this one is in my top five. The breakfast served here is amazing as well, albeit not a buffet.

reviews.name: A M.
reviews.review: Update: still keeping it at 3 stars. BP sent me a very informative message about their cold brewing process. +1 for contacting me. -1 for not offering to make a bad experience right.

reviews.name: Nathan A.
reviews.review: Barista Parlor is high quality stuff done right. It takes more time and is more expensive, but good stuff comes to folks who wait. The staff is borderline caricature hipster, but in my experience they aren't rude or flippant as some reviewers have said. The breakfast is pretty stinking good, but the coffee is where they shine. Lots of space and a cool outdoor spot for when its nice. If you went to BP and were a little put off by the price or service, this article might help explain the approach a bit more; en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Th…All in all if your focus is coffee, this is the spot.

reviews.name: Tristan S.
reviews.review: I don't normally leave reviews, but as a barista, I feel compelled to leave some input. Decor and feel of BP were great. And the selection of brewing methods leaves nothing to be desired. My 12 oz cold brew was delicious, (though it was half ice). My peach waffles were flavored very well, and the sausage was superb. I kept pausing in my conversation to enjoy the flavor. However, from what I could tell, the prices were majorly pretentious. My double shot was sweet and flavorful, but it should not have taken 20 minutes for an almost 5 dollar shot to reach my table. We waited for a long time for our food, and considering the fact that I dropped 20 bucks on a minimal amount of product, I would have expected faster service. Also, I'd like to choose my brewing method, rather than having it chosen for me for each roast. I'd probably give more stars if it weren't for high prices and slow service. Product was tasty. I'd definitely recommend a visit if you find yourself in the neighborhood. Just pick one thing and go with it.

reviews.name: Casey B.
reviews.review: The people who came to BP and gave it less than 4 stars: a) probably are fine with McDonald's coffee b) really like Starbucks c) don't care too much about high quality, 5 star coffee. But then there are people like me who seek out 5 star coffee for the excellence and experience. I don't want the burnt shit from Starbucks, unless I'm hurrying to work. Someone else here compared it to a 5 star hotel- you don't complain about THEIR style, you soak it in! Barista Parlor is serious about what they do. They want to serve the very best, and be the very best. And that's what they are. My husband ordered a macchiato, I forget which espresso he chose but you could really pick out the notes of berries and it was GREAT, and we shared a pourover of Handsome coffee. I drank the double barrel vanilla almond milk latte. Just the right amount of silky sweet.  If you take away anything, it is this: GET THE BISCUIT SANDWICH! I could live in it. I could eat it every day. But alas, I have to return to Austin and dream about it.

reviews.name: Alan W.
reviews.review: Every time we are in Nashville we stop at the Barista Parlor for a Bourbon Barrel Latte!

reviews.name: McAllen B.
reviews.review: Aa barista denied me ice cubes for my coffee because she didn't want me to "destroy the integrity of the product"..She didnt recommend against it.,she flat out refused.She told me I could order an iced coffee if that's what I wanted..I know she may think I'm a dipshit for putting ice in my coffee, but I did spend six dollars on it, and she should at least make a small attempt at hiding her disdain. I hope shes happy with the 20% tip I left her, because it'll be the last she ever gets from me or the five people I was with.EDIT: I feel as if I should note that the owner personally emailed me and apologized and explained that he has trained to the employees to adhere to strict recipe standards including water to grind ratios He also offered to buy me and my friends there next round. While, I believe that she(the barista) still approached the situation incorrectly, his quick response demonstrated humility and care, so I've revised my rating.

reviews.name: Ashwin M.
reviews.review: All hail the new Baristocracy!I am a coffee fanatic and an avid addict. I get my own green beans, roast them every other day, hand grind them to a fine brown pixie dust and use Aeropress to extract a delicious brew every time. So, when I realized that there was a new coffee shop in town that would give me the respect I deserved, I was excited.BP has a good vibe going for it. It is cavernous and tastefully decorated with a lot of distressed wooden furniture and chic accouterments. I wish they'd play some other type of music, but one does not visit BP for music. The coffee choices appear limited, but it's the journey that is important here, not the destination. As an amalgam of distills and beakers drip and bubble your coffee, one is transported to a semi-dream state, watching the baristas do their thing.I ding one star because the teas I had there a couple of times made me nauseous and the cold drip coffee served over ice cubes was not what I expected it to be, but their hot brews are phenomenal. I can't wait for the summer to die down so that warm beverages are back in vogue!

reviews.name: Nico N.
reviews.review: Don't let the inside/outside decor fool you! Yes, it looks very hip and that's what attractive our attention to go there. But once you get past the presentation and actually taste the food and coffee you will be very disappointed. Thats if you have 30 minutes to kill just to wait for coffee. That would have been understandable if it were busy but unfortunately that was not the case.

reviews.name: Maggie W.
reviews.review: "Best coffee shop in America" as purported by the national media-- hardly, but this place IS legit. Snooty barista in fancy apron? Check. Waiting an hour for your coffee? Yup. Some of the best coffee in town-- yes, totally. I stop here when I'm on the East Side mostly to check out the see-and-be-seen crowd (they never disappoint!), and thoroughly enjoy it each time. The coffee is consistently delicious and well crafted. I say totally go, but give yourself plenty of time and have a hearty sense of humor.

reviews.name: Margaret S.
reviews.review: Consistently good. Staff is kind an helpful, even to newcomers. Their biscuit with egg and cheese is definitely worth coming back for.

reviews.name: Drinko J.
reviews.review: Tell them what you're in the mood for and they will guide you.

reviews.name: Jasmine J.
reviews.review: The coffee and the sausage biscuit I ordered were both very tasty. They were also both expensive. It is quality coffee, so I excused that one, but my sausage biscuit alone was $8+ tax. Altogether coffee + biscuit+ tip ended up being around $15 unfortunately. They have a unique thing going, I just wish they could get their costs down a little. :(

reviews.name: Charles F.
reviews.review: If this is supposed to be some surrealist, Chris Morris style parody of the hip scene in Brooklyn / Portland, then 5 stars, but I'm assuming it isn't.Does it really matter if the coffee was good (it was ok) if it costs $4 a cup? In Tennessee?! I guess I didn't realise I was going to be subsidising the 1930s baseball clubhouse, vintage motorcycle garage, high school geography classroom cum hunting lodge, steampunk scientific research laboratory theme. Maybe I'm covering the loss they made when nobody bought any of those $125 vintage baseball caps in the corner?Unfortunately, it also doesn't really matter if your sausage, egg and cheese biscuit is really good and the service is pretty friendly. This place is way too silly and pretentious to be caught dead in.

reviews.name: Chris M.
reviews.review: The best sausage biscuit I've ever had! Totally worth the wait. The staff were knowledgeable, clean, friendly, and well dressed. The coffee was perfect. No need for cream or sugar. Black is the best way to enjoy the quality beans!

reviews.name: Alissa G.
reviews.review: If you're gluten free and sorely missing the breakfast sandwich experience, this is the place to go. The GF biscuit sandwiches will make your heart and tummy sing. The coffee is smooth. The atmosphere unique. Just make sure you have extra time to spare, because you're looking at a lengthy wait.

reviews.name: Sir Funky P.
reviews.review: Went in there today and I asked for an Americano (my coffee drink of choice) and they wouldn't make it for me because that's not how "they profile their espresso". I asked if they had hot water, they said yes. I asked if they had espresso, they said yes. When I asked if they could then make it for me using those ingredients he pointed to his menu and suggested other options the way they recommend espresso be consumed...speaking to me as if I've never had a pour over, latte or straight espresso before. I repeated my order, "12 oz Americano for here" and he rolled his eyes and said he'd check with a manager. Finally, they "approved" my order, charged me $4.50 and told me they'd bring it to me when it was ready. It came out no problem. As for the coffee, it was was full of acidity and extremely bitter. I wouldn't have minded frequenting this joint just because it's a nice place to read a book, but I'll probably never return. I recommend Barista Parlor get their nose out of the air, lower prices and start treating customers better.

reviews.name: Rachel G.
reviews.review: Great vibe. Awesome display and atmosphere. Come to do work, or hang with friends. Chill inside or outside. The vanilla bourbon coffee (got mine iced) was absolutely amazing. Didn't interact with many of the employees, but I did chat with Dominic! He was very personable and friendly. I'll be back for sure!

reviews.name: Bethany W.
reviews.review: A super hip vibe in East Nashville! We loved the reuse of the building, the interior design aesthetic, and the music as soon as we walked in. We also enjoyed the superb coffee and scones. This is a place to chill with a good friend or significant other all morning and just take in the experience.

reviews.name: Charlie B.
reviews.review: Finding this place is the first test. Along Gallatin, you will see shop after shop, but Barista Parlor is like a hipster's dream. I drove by it at least twice the first couple of times I went. It sits on the corner, by Rainbow Fashion, but back from the street, on the side of the building. The parking is a bit iffy, because you have to drive through the gates to get to it. This is not the place to get a quick coffee and go. The lines sometimes is out the door and the wait can be 30 minutes or longer just to get up to the register, however, their coffee is some of the best in Nashville. The baristas are extremely knowledgeable and although they may seem pretentious, are more than willing to explain to you anything you want to know about a drink they clearly have a passion for. Along with the experience comes a higher than normal price tag. At $4 for a simple carafe of coffee like the one shown, the cost may be prohibitive, however, I think it's worth it for all you get along with it. The seating in Barista Parlor is arranged around the central coffee making station and I really enjoy watching the baristas work. You can get coffee made in various ways, each a little different than the last. My favorite coffees are the Bourbon Barrel Vanilla Latte ($6/iced), the Caramel Latte or the Mocha. The regular coffees change periodically, but they are all delicious and, like I said, the baristas are more than happy to lead you through their slightly overwhelming menu full of not just different coffee options, but different preparations as well. Their food is excellent, though may not be particularly filling.

reviews.name: Conner H.
reviews.review: The food is excellent. The coffee is excellent (I've pretty much tried it all, and BP trumps). The facility is excellent. It's kind of on the pricy side, when it comes to "coffee shops" but you get what you pay for. Stop on by.

reviews.name: Emily L.
reviews.review: probably the coolest and most aesthetically pleasing coffee shop I've ever been to! service was awesome and very friendly, and of course the coffee was delicious (with dairy free milk options!). tons of amazing looking chocolate bars and pastries available as well

reviews.name: Lindsay G.
reviews.review: Food is good but takes forever to get served. Coffee is good but really you almost feel lime you have to be a fake hipster to even step foot in the place. I wish it was a little less upscale and more of just comfy place to eat. Furniture is wicked but not as "functional" as you would think. Too hipsterish for the norm folks around here.

reviews.name: Nancy V.
reviews.review: Love the place ... However: Had an almond milk latte with an extra shot of Wendelbo and suddenly coffee costs $7.50 #uh #hipsterfee

reviews.name: Matt W.
reviews.review: The coffee is good. Maybe not $5-for-a-tiny-cup good, but obviously well-crafted and complex. The service, however, seems to be more concerned with being cool than providing a memorable experience. I love bougie places, but this place is too much.

reviews.name: Kalla G.
reviews.review: This place is extremely overrated. The coffee was oddly fruity, the food was terrible, & the service was mediocre. I paid $14 for a breakfast sandwich & a coffee. Save your money & go somewhere else, this place is not worth it.

reviews.name: Tulané H.
reviews.review: My husband and I decided to finally check out the Barista Parlour today. The environment was beautifully decorated, trendy and typically "hipster", which we can both appreciate.  Upon walking in there was a short wait and a small menu, only one menu, to order from. My husband ordered one of their three biscuit choices (8 dollars ), there were no vegetarian options for me except for pastries, so I had a macaroon.... When asked about a simple egg they said they cooked those in lard (FYI not vegetarian). Still, I was a good sport and felt optimistic. My husband was delivered his crumbly, over salted biscuit on a plate the size of a drink coaster. Our 5 dollar coffees arrived 10 minutes later. We were informed cream and sugar were on the opposite side of the building, after the long trek we found there to be no creamer. At this point, my optimism was gone. Ridiculous to have to walk across a room and serve myself after paying an ungodly amount of money. When your food is delivered and drinks why after the delivery is it necessary for the customer to seek out cream and sugar? My husband felt he was a part of a circus act trying to eat his crumbling biscuit and catch the falling pieces on his tiny, bottled cap sized plate. The employees were polite, and they dressed very nicely.... It seems there is an emphasis on looking a certain way rather than focusing on service, speed, and catering to customers needs. Really ridiculous and disappointing, we really did want to like it.

reviews.name: Marcia M.
reviews.review: Barista Parlor will likely be upgraded to a 5 star review sooner than later but I have to set up my laptop there for a couple of hours before I can commit...I FINALLY made my way in for my inaugural visit after hearing fabulous things from my friends and network for months. I know that if I still lived on the East side that this would have have occurred months ago. My first impression was very positive as I loved the casual yet curated space and was instantly greeted by a barista who was polite and efficient with making my cup of "Stumptown" ($3.50). This elegant concoction consisted of Nano Challo with lemon, blueberry, chocolate, white peach, and cinnamon notes. The quality of my coffee surpassed my expectation meanwhile the cost was below what I fathomed. I was on the go so I had to roll out but I am itching to plug up and work here... loved the vintage record player and motorcycle that added a nostalgic touch to the spacious room. Tasty artisan products like chocolate and coffees we thoughtfully merchandised throughout the space and a edited yet enticing menu offered up some bites too. Don't be surprised if my check-ins become rapidly frequent here.

reviews.name: Danielle S.
reviews.review: So this isn't your everyday cup of joe. This is a leisurely adventure. We were on a road trip and heard this place was great. Yes we waited about 15 minutes in line with probably 5 people in front of us, but there were goodies to look at and tempt you. The people of front were passing the menu back so everyone could figure out what they wanted. We ended up with a Whisky something latte and a vanilla bourbon latte. It took forever but as you can tell from watching them, it was definitely a craft experience. No starbucks here. We also ordered the moto biscuit and the frenchman. The frenchman was just a plate of eggs, honey cornbread and bacon. Very simple but well made. My moto bucuit was delicious with sausage. I only wish the biscuit was a little softer so it didn't fall apart as much. Ate it with a fork after too many attempts and the biscuit going everywhere. Yeah it's a little pricey but it was a unique experience. At our concert later that night Afie Jurvanen, even said he had been there earlier that morning as well because he heard about it and went to support the economy with an $8 cup of coffee.

reviews.name: Inness P.
reviews.review: I visited Nashville for the first time the other week and this place was right around the corner from the place I stayed. I visited for breakfast one morning with the two friends who were traveling with me. As others have said, this place is hipster with a capital H, but since I'm from Seattle (and arguably one of the more hipstery neighborhoods), I am inured to hipsterness; I did not mind and actually loved it. Is appears to be a requirement that the baristas sport beards; the whole rustic/industrial thing is going on; and the music is pumped through rehabilitated old radio speakers. My friends ordered a black coffee and a chocolate milk (they really only do coffee, so if you don't do coffee, milk it is!); I had an iced coffee. We also ordered breakfast foods - biscuit sandwiches for two of us, waffles for the other. Things are indeed on the pricey side; I paid about $16 for my order. To me, it was worth it, because everything was DELICIOUS. I would go back in a heartbeat if I ever visit Nashville again.

reviews.name: Donald H.
reviews.review: Nice coffee. Nice food. A bit pricy (I spent 12 bucks on a cappuccino and a breakfast sandwich). And I feel it was way too noisy. I'd go back. Give it a shot if you are in town.

reviews.name: Mehgan H.
reviews.review: This is a little place of paradise off of Gallatin Road!A friend and myself went here the other day and it was my first time. It was simply amazing!! At first you think, really? Off of Gallatin Rd...here? But as soon as you enter the gates (literally) - you feel like you are in a whole new world!The ambiance in here is amazing. It's so trendy and chic, but yet it has it's southern charm. I got a Caramel Latte and it was divine. One of the best coffee's that I've had in a while - and I am definitely a coffee expert. I did not try and of the foods but I will definitely be going back soon and that is on my agenda.You need to give this place a try.

reviews.name: Phil N.
reviews.review: Before I get to the bad stuff, let me say that based on the flavor of the cappuccino and the chocolate chip cookie I got here the rating would be a 5-star... if only... the guy at the counter wasn't such a pompous (guy). They did not have a decaf cap... and when I asked what they could do in decaf, he said there were some teas available. I clearly wanted a coffee drink of some kind, guy, don't tell me to get a tea. I then said caf would be fine but can he do a non-fat cap? No. They only have whole milk. Seriously? What kind of place doesn't have any offerings that are not even out of the ordinary? You're too cool to offer decaf and too cool to offer a non-fat or low fat option? Then he had the balls to ask if I still wanted the drink and the cookie... as if I was about to walk out... or he didn't give a (darn) if I ordered anything. I still ordered and he didn't offer a thanks or anything. Worst service I've gotten in Nashville. Go buy a new hipster shirt with the minimum wage you're earning, guy. Terrible.To think they sell a $125 baseball cap and a $30 coffee tumbler. This ain't San Francisco, holmes. This is East Nashville. Still, the huge space inside with hip music, cool wood tables and chairs and good offering of beans (including SF's FourBarrel) would be a cool place to chill. Nashville's coffee scene (can you call it a scene if it sucks?) is limited to Crema and... well... Crema. So simply based on the coffee, this place is good  enough if you can stand the stuck up dude in an apron.

reviews.name: Andy F.
reviews.review: Ambiance:I absolutely love the vibe here. I'm here now and all 4 garage doors are wide open. I love that on this perfect fall day. Everyone is super nice. Great music selection playing. Wifi is fast enough, only 3 laptops in here right now though.Food/Drink:Iced Mocha and Sausage Biscuit are amazing. Didn't have to wait 10 minutes for my order.Complaints:Power outlets. There are only 3 spots in here where you can plug in. One is a high top table on the side that 2 people can fit at. The other 2 are at each end of the long bar that's facing straight into the back wall. This place is so cool I don't want to sit right up against/facing the back wall. I guess it limits people from sitting here all day but this is a standard at most coffee shops. I would rate this a 5/5 if it had a couple more spots to plug in.Only other thing is of the 5 large tables, 3 of them have the chairs with no backs on them. They look like mini stools. I love me some back rests if I'm doing work.Bottom line I would hate to come here and get stuck at one of the tables with no back rests and no power outlets.

reviews.name: Ryan R.
reviews.review: This is in my top three coolest coffee shops I've been too and I seek them out. The people here were polite and helpful NOT SNOBBY like manny coffee shops of this caliber.  Had a latte and their Huntsman breakfast. The latte was pretty much perfect. Great espresso taste and perfectly textured milk. Good art as well. The breakfast was a little overpriced for the portion but it was very good! Amazing experience I will be back.

reviews.name: Meagan M.
reviews.review: This is a super personal review, this place was not for me. If your looking for uber-trendy, hipster mecca, may spot a celeb incognito then yeah this is the place for you.  If you like your coffee made with the "anti-pomp" that is the hipster existence then again you will love it.  I just wasn't impressed with the coffee or service.  The artfully crafted wooden menus were beautiful and the layout and design was interesting but I won't be going back.  I'll just stick to the good 'ole hole in the wall joint.

reviews.name: Alishah N.
reviews.review: Do you watch Jerry Seinfeld's web-show Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee?There's an episode from Season 2 with Sara Silverman. Jerry and Sara walk into a coffee shop sit down and wait... and wait... and Jerry says: "You know what the problem is here? I think we'll be suffering from Hipster-Service here..."And that basically breaks down Barista Parlor for me. They have a limited menu is not on display - instead, it's on tiny wooden placards that you can only see once your up at the register (so there's no chance to be prepared.) This creates a long line up as people only get their first chance to explore the menu when they have to order.Ingredients run out. Fast. So by the time you make your way through the entire line up your options are fairly limited.They have good coffee options, but it still takes a while to get to you. Hipster service.They could be a great place, but the problem is they are focused too much on having a certain look/feel/vibe, and less about actually getting people their food and/or coffee.To be clear: I had to wait 10 minutes for my latte, and then another 45 minutes for my egg and cheese biscuit. 45 minutes.

reviews.name: Tart L.
reviews.review: Yupsters from the Gulch condos enjoy sipping Andy Mumma's coffee in an old music building between the Icon and Yazoo. The Golden Sound site has been converted to a new Barista Parlor coffee spot. The big black Roaster is the heart of this new coffeehouse, and will be fired up later. The BP's soul is in the room next to the roasting room. The soul is the work of the baristas in the middle of the bright coffee crafting room. Only a thin glass wall separates the two rooms. Wait time is half as long since there are now two serving stations, two lines, two hand-crafted Slayer espresso makers. In two corners of the room are also groups of four glass cold-brew drip coffee stills with delicate spiral glass tubes for the coffee to slowly trikle down into the pots. Bottomline is that speed is not the axiom here. Slow, careful quality is. It's craft coffee. So if you're rushed, go to charbucks. A few bites from an Olive & Sinclair chocolate bar is a good climax to the coffee crafting. Or you could adulterate the barista's brew with some chocolatiers chunks when he's not looking. (The proud baristas prefer folks drink their coffee as pure as presented.) The premium BP coffee crafting is premium priced, but worth it to the yupster and hipster coffee snobs who wait patiently for their fix of Barista Parlor cold-brew / drip / pour-over coffee. Patience is a virtue.

reviews.name: Bridgette C.
reviews.review: Dear East Nashville, I get so insanely mad when you have cool little joints pop up like daisies.  Especially when this aforementioned coffee addict hears there's a sweet coffee place to be had across yonder river.  I grumble every time I must cross into your borders to see what the fuss is about only to be once again humbled that yes, it was worth the stupid drive.  Why must you open such a fantastic little (speaking figuratively since this place is HUGE on the inside and outside) coffeehouse with hand-poured coffee and yummy little noshes?  Why must you provide so much space to post up with my laptop and work on my schoolwork, and be worlds cooler and more delicious than that crap Starbucks calls coffee?  I'd ask why you feel the need for a record player but then I remember where I am.  There's a beautiful outdoor space for sitting that I will surely be trying out come warmer weather, complete with old trucks for decoration.  I guess I'll have to buy skinny jeans, roll them up, pack up my (non-Apple) laptop and head over to actually get work done since this is a good place for that, and also for learning about local shows (see the awesome board by the bathrooms) and maybe meeting friends for a caffeine boost.  East Nashville, we are obviously having an illicit affair and I will ask you not to tell Midtown ok?  Sincerely, a coffee-loving science nerd.

reviews.name: Coffee S.
reviews.review: OK... I am a coffee snob.  I love good coffee.  This place has that.  The only reason I can't give it 5 stars is because it literally often take 20+ minutes to get your coffee or food.  Its weird.  Even when it isn't very busy, it seems to take far too long.  But, as I said... I am a coffee snob... so I'll wait... again... and again...

reviews.name: Dane G.
reviews.review: Best thing I can say about this place is it looks cool. If you like your coffee the way they think you should like your coffee then this is the place for you! Special requests are frowned upon! If you are a first timer you will be made to feel uncomfortable and will probably end up ordering something you don't really like just to not hold up the line! Their coffee is average and overpriced. They are totally trying too hard to be cool! I moved here from Seattle and I am not a fan of chain coffee shops so I was really looking forward to trying this place. Save your money... get a nespresso and make it from home!

reviews.name: Amanda K.
reviews.review: Neat, neat place with killer coffee.While staying and exploring around East Nashville I stumbled upon this place on an afternoon walk.  I am a coffee lover (well let's be honest, a latte lover!) so I was super happy to find a good coffee shop while in uncharted territory.The space is open, bright, and inviting and once you pick a seat your love for this place grows as you enjoy your drink of choice!  I tried both the iced vanilla and iced caramel lattes, both of which were great.  I could have done without them being served in mason jars because I am ready for that trend to die off already, but the taste of both drinks was spot on!Didn't get a chance to try the food, but it looked delicious.  Will definitely stop here for breakfast next time I visit Nashville!

reviews.name: Robin W.
reviews.review: Very hipster and might be slightly intimidating to some but the staff was extremely friendly.  The food was delicious and the coffee was great.  We had a very good experience here!

reviews.name: Kim Y.
reviews.review: What if Imogene + Willie ( yelp.com/biz/imogene-and…) had a baby with a french press guys?? Obviously you'd get Barista Parlor!While I still miss Roast's more unassuming store front, Barista Parlor really does take its coffee as seriously - they just don't roast their own. At first I wasn't sure if I could take the set-up seriously. Its like hipster puke; but the wonderful Dozen Bakery cookie samples whetted my appetite and I could tell this wasn't all style driven.Great iced coffee after a hot yoga class and my friends Porter Road breakfast sausage biscuit was tasty as well - although at $5 for a little sammie I would have needed 2, for a $15 breakfast and coffee. Ouch.Not an everyday place, but a cute little addition to the 'hood. I'll stick to my Bongo East for after class, but would not be opposed to meeting someone at Barista Parlor to chillax.Just remind me to bring my own splenda - I can make my own decisions about whether or not I want to 'ruin' your coffee with my tasty chemicals. ;D

reviews.name: Emma W.
reviews.review: Very cool atmosphere. Very cool cold-brew technique. Great coffee. No vegan or gluten free food options...which was surprising in East Nashville. I was frowned upon for asking for almond milk with my coffee, which was off-putting. Amazing Vanilla bourbon-aged latte. Pricey. Still very unique coffee shop.

reviews.name: Kat J.
reviews.review: I am writing this review mostly on behalf of my friends and I will start out by saying that Barista Parlor has the best latte I have ever had and having moved here as a coffee snob from Portland, that's a pretty big deal to me... But though the quality of their coffee is high - their customer service is among the worst in the city.  Not in a funny "Soup Nazi" kind of way.  The wait times for their coffee are inexcusable. (Up to 45 minutes or an hour.). Even a cold brew or an iced tea can take up to 25 minutes.  And the staff isn't nice enough to their customers or apologetic enough for the crazy wait times and bad service to justify opening 2 new locations in the city.  IF they would up their game by creating a culture of speed, quality, and amazing kindness- this place would be totally unstoppable and I would champion it with everything I had.  But at their luxury coffee price point with nothing but luxury coffee to pull me in, I will come in less and take the great customer service and friendliness of Crema and Frothy monkey over BP for most of my coffee needs.  But if their work culture were to change...

reviews.name: Twinkle W.
reviews.review: This place was very hip and fun to be at. The staff is pleasant and helpful. The coffee is varied and delicious. The food is absolutely yummy. There is clearly a faithful crowd of regulars but also newcomers seem to be coming through. Definitely worth your time and money.

reviews.name: Jacob T.
reviews.review: Just the people who get Coffee at this place make me not want to go in there. Barista Parlor knows about as much about Coffee as The Black Keys know about music: NOTHING!

reviews.name: Trixie M.
reviews.review: Such a cool environment!  It is very hipster, but in a good way.  The environment was very warm and inviting.  Beautiful setup both in and outside.  The coffee was fantastic, all the way from the taste to the way it was "presented."  Some things to be aware of though.  First, it's easy to miss if you haven't been there before.  I drove by it a few times before finding it because it's tucked in back of a lot.  Second, I was a little intimidated when I first walked in because I didn't know where to go to order.  (FYI it's the bench looking area to the left of the door)  Then once I found it I didn't understand the menu.  I am an avid coffee shop goer of all kinds, and this one sort of threw me for a loop.  Luckily the gal working was super friendly and helpful when my friend and I told her this was our first visit.  Third, it is pricey.  $5 for a smallish mason jar of iced coffee.  I think it was worth it for the quality, service and the ambiance, but just be aware if you're on a budget.

reviews.name: heather r.
reviews.review: Barista Parlor isn't cheap and it isn't fast. It is high quality, made with care with every ingredient is identified. It is also a part of the community in East Nashville, something that just feels good if this your neighborhood. I appreciate the care and creativity in all of their specialty drinks and core coffees and teas. I will gladly wait 10 minutes and pay $6 for a coffee, over and over.They have been careful about introducing only a few food items at a time and have gotten them all right. Their in-house baker is really great. Best macaron in Nashville hands-down. Oh and the chocolate, holy shit, the chocolate. They make their coffees with that amazing chocolate too. Don't be intimidated by the decor or the patrons or the different way of doing things. The baristas are super friendly and helpful and will guide you through the process and make recommendations. This is why there's a line sometimes, it's not the quik-stop of coffee.

reviews.name: Hannah S.
reviews.review: This is the most pretentious coffee shop I have ever been to. They do not offer any decaf.My friend asked for tea, and they asked her to go get the canister off the wall for them. What?This place is 100% image and bizarro service and offerings. I will say this for them--they have free wifi.

reviews.name: S S.
reviews.review: We stopped here based on reviews, and they were spot on. The coffee is AMAZING! The place is cool too. It's superduperhipster, but if you can roll with that-these ppl are artists.The salt caramel Tennessee whiskey latte is the best I've ever had. Perfect combo of salty/not too sweet.

reviews.name: Allison B.
reviews.review: Barista Parlor is everything I want in coffee shop. The staff knows their coffee. The person who took our order was excited about the coffees he had to offer. I ended up ordering the bourbon barrel vanilla latte and a sausage biscuit. It took a while for our coffee to arrive but it was well worth the wait. The space and the decor is very inviting a relaxing. I love the vintage touches and music was great. I think I have found my new Saturday morning tradition.

reviews.name: Jen B.
reviews.review: Amazing place with a great Nashville vibe. Reasonable price, I has the whiskey caramel latte and my sister had the bourbon vanilla latte - we both loved them. Definitely stop here, just saw Jack White!!! Hanging out wondering who else might come in... Worth stopping here and I'll be back!

reviews.name: Jackson W.
reviews.review: I've waited a while to write this review just to be sure that it was honest and also that Barista Parlor was consistent. I tried to be as impartial as possible and write a purely objective review. I failed.Barista Parlor serves the best coffee in Nashville. Barista Parlor has the best espresso in Nashville. Barista Parlor attends to every detail in the creation of delicious, high-quality hot beverages. It doesn't end there, though. Barista Parlor looks cool. Barista Parlor smells good. Barista Parlor has delicious food from local purveyors.Perhaps the most important is the fact that Barista Parlor has been unceasingly improving since it opened; I'm excited to see it keep growing. They might need two cashiers, though.

reviews.name: Elizabeth B.
reviews.review: Just moved to East Nashville and its by far the best tasting coffee and brunch around! I love the atmosphere as well :)

reviews.name: Molly O.
reviews.review: Super hip place. Must get a latte with almond milk. The almond milk makes it sweet enough where you don't need anything else! Wish they had more latte variety, but very good! Their biscuits are out of this world.

reviews.name: Beth W.
reviews.review: Worth The Wait...Great Bourbon Vanilla Latte W/Almond Milk. Sausage,Egg & Butter Milk Biscuit Hit The Spot Too!

reviews.name: Amy W.
reviews.review: This is hipster to the n-th degree. The baristas have artisan aprons and vinyl records to buy. I thought great maybe with the 10-ish coffees they have available, they would have a great decaf coffee. There is NO DECAF. No I don't want a tea I came for coffee. There isn't even decaf espresso. Ridiculous. I love coffee, but I gave up caffeine for lent. Ended up at crema, which is just the right amount of hipster for me.

reviews.name: Lora L.
reviews.review: I loved this place - from the motorcycles to the ZZ Top on the turntable to the open vibe and wait, the coffee!  Intelligentsia, Stumptown, Counter Culture - some of my faves and all in one place!  My friend Phil was put of by one of the hipsters working there but I felt the service was pretty neutral - neither here for there...it was the atmosphere & coffee I was all about.  Are they a little pretentious, maybe?  But I am a person who paid $30 for less than a lb of coffee at Crema so who am I to judge?  I will say it was one of the nicest pours of a cappuccino I've ever had and really, that's all I'm coming for to begin with so #winning ; )

reviews.name: Jeremy D.
reviews.review: I really wanted to like this place, but there is nothing positive to say about it other than the visual appeal.  It takes way too long for service, it's far too expensive, the baristas are too hip to be useful in any capacity, and, after all, the coffee is just okay and the scone I had was downright inedible.  Also, I'm really not sure where one is meant to park when visiting the BP.  It's a really cool space but I could hardly bring myself to sit there for more than the time it took to make the damn coffee.

reviews.name: Natalie F.
reviews.review: To summarize BP in a few words:Quality coffee. Hipster baristas. Motorcycles. Local produce. Artisan. Yup, it's hipster city. However, I don't care. The laid back atmosphere and the attention to detail (in the coffee, food, and aesthetic of the place) is enough for me to want to come back.  I am no coffee connoisseur, but that Salty Whiskey Caramel Latte (try it iced!) is so dang good that even if this place sucked all around I would still go back for it. The reason your coffee takes a while to be made: quality. Their food isn't terribly complicated to make which is why it comes out faster. Its mostly local and very fresh. As long as you have an appreciation for details, you'll be satisfied here. However I do agree with another reviewer on here who I think mentioned the chairs/stools. They have no back, which can be a little harsh when you're sitting there for awhile either doing work on your laptop or catching up with a friend. Also -- if you love documenting cool artisan places, I don't think you can get one bad angle trying to take a picture of this place -- it's perfectly decorated and put together.

reviews.name: Amanda H.
reviews.review: loved the environment, was good food but not the price, and the coffee was good too!

reviews.name: Anne M.
reviews.review: I do not love their coffee. I drink my coffee black but do appreciate a good speciality drink once in a  blue moon. Their coffee doesn't have a unique taste to me, it's just okay. I just have never enjoyed their speciality drinks either, in my opinion they are way to milky and sugary.

reviews.name: Neal M.
reviews.review: If you've found yourself in Barista Parlor, Congratulations. You're a hipster!  Hehehehe just kidding!  Or am I?  If you like a good cup of coffee and don't mind paying nearly $5 for it, this is a place for you to go.  Just be warned, damn near EVERY dude in here looks like the missing member of Mumford & Sons or something.

reviews.name: Michael B.
reviews.review: I only come here a few times a year... A cup of coffee and a breakfast biscuit sandwich will run you about $12.  I can do that at home for a week for a little more than the same amount. I can buy the same 'artisan hand crafted' beans these guys use, make a farm to table egg sandwich and be on the internet at home.  But, I do like to take in a little people watching while savoring my high dollar coffee... Am I reading that right? $125 for a ball cap....bet those are flying off the shelf...get a grip BP...remember, cool and hip is in the eye of the customer...no matter how hard you may try or think you are. It's coffee flavored water for cryin' out loud....and it's readily available in many less pretentious establishments... I enjoy the BP but I couldn't afford nor would I be able to hang here every day.

reviews.name: Michael T.
reviews.review: Very good drinks (I tried their bourbon one and their whisky one).  Not the best I've ever had (and perhaps not the best in town), but their drinks (lattes/mochas) are definitely very, very good.  Worth the cost, and worth going.  But here's why you go:  the ambiance.  This place is C-O-O-L cool.  One of the coolest coffee shops I've ever been to.  Loved it, right down to the record player.  The entire set-up is fantastic.  I look forward to going back.  The food selection was minimal, so I can't recommend it for breakfast.  Just go check it out, and have some coffee while you're there.

reviews.name: Queen B.
reviews.review: I did not know this place existed until today when I was brought here for a cup of tea and macaroons.Wow!  Talk about surprise!This afternoon, we were waiting on a car to be repaired and stopped in here, out the cold wet afternoon for a cup of tea and some macaroons.The macaroons melted in my mouth, filled with marmalade.Had some kind of wonderful blend of hot tea, that was brewed just right.Sat down and enjoyed my afternoon tea and looked around at all the people that knew about this place, before me!Everyone was on their MacBooks, plugged into music, drinking tea and eating snacks...I love the atmosphere here and the best part?  No crying babies like over at Bongo Java..So many choices of coffee, tea, chocolate, biscuits... you name it.and the space is so big, and spacious, I didn't have to listen to the conversation next to me.Love this place. My new favorite afternoon stop.

reviews.name: Meghan E.
reviews.review: The best breakfast biscuit I have ever had.  The Southern Frenchman was awesome, we also ordered one of the platters and it was great, perfect portions in my opinion.  Atmosphere was great and I did't pick up on any of the service issues that some of the other reviewers mentioned.  Its great to go to a coffee shop that feels open and airy, not overly crowded and loud.  Oh and the coffee, fantastic!

reviews.name: Samantha S.
reviews.review: This coffee shop is slow, pricey and a bit pretentious but once you can get past that, it's all good.  The product you receive is definitely worth the wait!  I love the Iced Bourbon Barrel Vanilla Latte (5.50) when I'm craving something sweet but my go-to is the first drip coffee on the top left side of the menu (can't remember the name)  It's pretty basic but oh so good!  These people know what they're doing!The space is so gorgeous and I like spending time in here.   It's a great place for a girly catch-up coffee date!

reviews.name: Jessica W.
reviews.review: This place needs some serious customer service improvements!!  After a group of customers gathered near the register waiting to order (there is NO sign or order to the line!), the barista comes up 4-5minutes later to acknowledge the crowd and says "The line forms this way".....we all awkwardly get in order.  The only menu is at the register, so unless you are a regular, you have no idea what they have, AND it adds time to the ordering process for each customer.After we FINALLY got to order our breakfast.  ($11 for coffee & a biscuit) The food came out about 10 minutes later.  The coffee came out 10 minutes LATER!  We ate our food before our coffee even came and my latte came out before my friend's regular coffee.  Things are in serious disorder at this place.People don't want to spend that kind of money for poor service and pretentious baristas.  Get another register, put up a menu, make a sign that says LINE FORMS HERE, and get on the ball!  Otherwise, people will go somewhere else.  You can bet I will!

reviews.name: Zac S.
reviews.review: OH, OK. I GET IT. Barista Parlor is a super-awesome-crazy-cool hipster hangout. It uses an espresso machine that cost more than my car (when it was new), cranks out indie tunes, has what I assume are reclaimed wood tables, hangs artisan lightbulbs, and features a huge pixelated mural of a boat at sea. On top of that, the employees are all dressed in clothes/aprons from Nashville's hottest homegrown designers.  This has resulted in the place being featured in the NY times and countless other publications (both local and national). If this place had booze to go along with the caffeine, internet, and sparse food menu (which is admittedly delicious), it would be a one stop hipster shop.Now, please don't be discouraged by all of the hipster-dad chestpieces you see when you walk in here. Just embrace it! I've always subscribed to the "hipsters create cool things" credo, and despite the fact that my rant above suggests otherwise, I think this place has some good stuff to offer. The décor, although maybe a bit contrived, is pretty damn cool. The coffee is good and crafted with care. The PRB sausage biscuit with peach preserves is fantastic. And, the selection of artisan chocolates (including Mast Brothers from Brooklyn) is very good.I suppose my only complaint is with the pricing/sizing structure. I've gotten the bourbon and vanilla latte two times. The first time, I got it there. I got the bigger size, which was either $5 or $6 (a little pricey to begin with), but it came in one of those big, wide latte mugs. It was delicious. The second time, I got it to go. I got the smaller size, which is only $1 less if I remember correctly, and it basically came in one of those 2 oz. Dixie cups my parents keep in their bathroom. It was still delicious, but the size just made it feel like a rip-off.All in all, don't be afraid to throw on your Tom's, roll up your jeans, hop on your fixie, and ride over there. Just be prepared for your Portlandia-esque experience.

reviews.name: David R.
reviews.review: Been here a few times now and must say that this place delivers a great coffee experience.  The layout is open and airy and the coffee is prepared with competence and care.  I understand that Crema also pulls good espresso shots, so I can't say that BP is "the best" espresso in town, but it's about as good as you can get.  I haven't tried any of the other coffee drinks at BP but trust the other reviewers who say that their hand-pour coffee is superlative as well.Some people here are saying there's some pretentiousness at BP but I didn't experience it.  FWIW, I think that a lot of people confuse pretentiousness with pride-in-work and, while those attitudes can sometime *appear* similar, they are stemming from from two, distinct motivations.  BP seems to be coming for the perspective of the integrity of the coffee rather than some image of the coffee drinker.

reviews.name: Corey W.
reviews.review: Really liked this place, expected baristas to be a little cold but they were really friendly. If I lived in East Nashville I would be there often.

reviews.name: Ben P.
reviews.review: Just have to say, this is one of the coolest coffee shops I've ever been to. Every corner of the place is photograph worthy; I felt like I was in some coffee-addicted mad scientist's laboratory. They could have charged more for their coffee (other shops in the area DO charge more) but I'm not complaining. I am currently sitting at a communal table overseeing the barista working station, and I don't think I'm going to leave for quite some time.

reviews.name: Tony W.
