reviews.review: Cappuccino was like 4 ounces but it taste like heaven made.  Not exactly cheap but it is not Dunkin Donuts.  The deco is very inviting. Great place to start a long date night.

reviews.name: Jessica S.
reviews.review: Tried again, bow I have learned my lesson. Two people in front of me, six baristas. 45 minutes later my coffee appeared.

reviews.name: Mark V.
reviews.review: This is my favorite place to get a coffee and a biscuit (I recommend the Moto Biscuit and add Benton's Bacon). The place is a little eclectic with the combination of nautical and cafe racer inspired decor. The background music is eclectic as well and could just as easily be RUN DMC one hour and Fleetwood Mac the next as it's served up via 12" vinyl. Primitive wood tables and stools are beautiful contrast to the modern mosaic in the back of the shop. Oh, and back to the coffee, the coffee is always fantastic and brewed with the most zen of brewing techniques. I do wish they served decaf espresso for those of us that can't handle caffeine everyday. If they do then I'll be over there a couple of times a week vs once every few weeks. Now where are they going to put a "BP" on the west side of town?

reviews.name: Caitlin D.
reviews.review: Great decor, wide open space with tall ceilings, cool art on the walls, interesting furniture... definitely the coolest looking coffee shop around. I only wish they had some stronger/darker brews, as I like my coffee to resemble rocket fuel and their darkest variety left me craving my home-made sludge. If you are normal, however, you will probably love their coffee and this won't be an issue for you. It's such a great space, you have to check it out for yourself.

reviews.name: Libby B.
reviews.review: I'm not sure what I was expecting when I first walked in here, but it wasn't what I saw. They appear to have taken an auto shop and renovated it into this really nice, open coffee shop space. The deco is nice, they even have real motorcycles in the front! And the garage doors let just enough light in without blinding customers. I definitely enjoyed the layout.I'm not a coffee drinker usually, but the latte I had (I believe there was "bourbon" in the name, and I couldn't pass that up!) was extremely tasty. I'm very curious to try their selection of tea as well.The food selection is quite nice here; traditional coffee-shop staples like scones and muffins live in the front display, but you can also order things like waffles. They also feature various brands of artisan chocolates at their register, which all look extremely tasty. On my visit I ordered the waffles, and they were delicious. Of note: if you order bacon, they only bring you one piece. This made me sad. (although I'm sure I could have asked for more, at a charge.)As nice as this place is, it is not the kindest thing for your wallet. (The $3 for a stick of chocolate the size of my finger definitely threw me.) It definitely couldn't be my go to coffee place, but for the occasional morning or afternoon when I'm in the area and want to relax with a book for a bit, it's certainly not bad, and if you haven't gone, it's definitely worth checking out.

reviews.name: A R.
reviews.review: The atmosphere here is really unique and the biscuits are delicious, but I have an issue with them not offering any decaf options! What about the pregnant women?? The service is also outrageously slow, I understand that it's not Starbucks or some rushed coffee place, but really - why does it take so long?

reviews.name: SG P.
reviews.review: Amazing and unique coffee choices!

reviews.name: Alyssa H.
reviews.review: The only thing saving Barista Parlor from a 1 Star Review is the fact that their iced coffee is delicious. However, I rarely drink iced coffee.My favorite drink is a soy au lait."We don't DO au laits."WHAT?How do you not do au laits?!"We only do coffee or lattes."Okay, you have coffee and you have soy milk, so... I don't get it. They're called "Barista" Parlor, but they can't make au laits.Disappointed, I ordered the Sidamo, thinking maybe the blueberry notes would make me feel better about missing out on the drink I wanted. Unfortunately, the "barista" didn't listen to me and I got a cup of the other Ethiopian blend. :'(About the seating... I have no idea who chose the seating for this place, but they did not take tall people into consideration. My bf is over 6 foot tall. The chairs and tables that are lower looked incredibly uncomfortable, so we opted for the seating with the tabletops attached to the wall. The cables running across them were in just the right spot that it was awkward to try to have a conversation around them.So, the coffee is overpriced, the service pathetic, and the seating is less than ideal. Never again.

reviews.name: Jessica L.
reviews.review: The operators of this establishment don't know how to operate a restaurant and would be better off limiting themselves to a coffee bar. They only have 2 copies of the menu making ordering an extremely cumbersome process that isn't customer friendly. Also the menu would be significantly improved by including any kind of fruit and vegetable. Today it is primarily starch, meat and cheese with the occasional jam or jelly.

reviews.name: Jonathan R.
reviews.review: I tend to dine here early, so I may be missing the avalanche of hipster that I read about. Regardless, aren't we all so post youth, now. Geez.Barista Parlor has hit their stride, I believe. Their statement of purpose, wherever Brice has letterpressed it, is intact as they undoubtedly attend to a day-to-day procession of coffee-chain soaked patrons that are curious or those that have realized, and are chelating with quality beans/process. There is very little talk about it all, just showing. Their creative furniture, tableware, menus, layout can be criticized for an unconventional awkwardness, but it all does an appropriate job of nudging us to smell our espresso before drinking. Yep, you're right - I do taste plum.

reviews.name: kimberly f.
reviews.review: You better have A LOT of time on your hands if you're visiting this place. A regular coffee takes 30 minutes...ridiculous.

reviews.name: Stomping S.
reviews.review: Favorite cup of coffee in Nashville.Having lived here 7 years ago, this is a far cry from Fido, Bongo Java, and Portland Brew, which all have a special place in my heart.Try a pour over and sausage biscuit. If you think it's too fancy or pricey, give it another shot. There are different types of coffee shops; this one's about as good as it gets in the quality column.One negative, on maybe 1 of 4 visits the service was exceptionally slow. That could improve.

reviews.name: Dustin O.
reviews.review: I went to other places before here they were packed so I ended up here. The vibe was REALLY nice I figure out how to order etc & go to order. That's when I find out there are 2 options for someone who doesn't eat pork. A waffle or a biscuit at with sausage on it cost sans sausage. There's a egg meal with pork of course I asked can I get the waffle & egg on the side & was told I couldn't. It's a nice joint coffees great but I would frequent more if a brother could get a decent breakfast swine free IJS.

reviews.name: Roberto W.
reviews.review: Definitely the coolest coffee bar I have ever been to.  The coffee and teas that we enjoyed were very good.  But the space is just amazing.  They have old motorcycles at the entrance, flags hanging on the walls and a lot of wood and metal all over the warehouse.  There is no Starbucks like line to order your drinks on.  You just order to a guy behind a desk.  All of the people preparing the coffee are in the middle of the space with no real separation from the customers.  For the teas, you just grab the tub that has the tea you want and give it to them for brewing.  Really nice concept they created in Nashville.

reviews.name: Heidi E.
reviews.review: LOVE the decor except for I didn't know where I could and couldn't walk to avoid being behind the counter (extremely open design concept). Love that it is an old garage- amazing lighting.It's one of the few places in Nashville that has almond milk which I seriously appreciate as a vegan who doesn't like soy milk.They don't offer decaf (too coffee snobbish to condescend to decaf I suppose), not good for a nursing mother (which I am).And there were no vegan food choices, which I found shocking. Such a hipster coffee connoisseur high brow place like this should have vegan food, or at least one option. Very disappointing.And it's hard to find, but  maybe that makes it cooler. Maybe that makes it too cool.

reviews.name: Robert M.
reviews.review: This morning was my second visit to Barista Parlor and here are my thoughts:Pros:  -Great tasting coffee; -delicious sausage, egg, cheese biscuit; -prompt delivery of my FOOD order; -friendly, knowledgeable staff (one lady was extremely helpful in explaining their fancy chocolates); -I really like how organized and clean the barista station looks, especially since its the center piece of the room;  Cons:-my food got cold as I waited for my coffee-when it's cold outside, it's cold inside-no skim or 2% milk at "sugar" station-no outlets

reviews.name: travis allen a.
reviews.review: Alright, let's be real here. Instead of a number or some sort of flag when you order food, they give you a small wooden child on a stick. It is absolutely ridiculous to carry that thing around while finding a place to sit. And the wait time for food, coffee beverages, price points, etc. all kind of annoy the shit out of me... but the product is great quality, they showcase lots of awesome roasters from all over the globe, and have a unique atmosphere, so I can't dock them too much. Plus, when you go to a place like this, you kind of know the ropes. More power to ya, craft coffee oasis. Just move like you drank some coffee a little more.

reviews.name: Kristin Marie S.
reviews.review: I wish I could review this place but I can't.  I was pretty excited to give them a go, but I went in, tried to order a decaf coffee and was shut down immediately.  I then asked for any decaf options and they said, "uh, we may have some chamomile tea."    No thanks, even Stumptown in Portland was able to make me a killer decaf option.  (They offer a no chemical treated decaf as well as a vanilla bean Italian soda.  Baller!)  I know decaf is looked down upon but believe it or not some people can't drink it for health reasons.  Sure you may not believe in it, but it's a courtesy.  Since they couldn't extend that courtesy, I took my business to Sip and ordered a tasty decaf latte.  It also came with a pretty leaf on top.

reviews.name: Chris H.
reviews.review: Quick summation. Service was lackluster. Coffee was mediocre. Atmosphere was pretentious. Wouldn't recommend unless you care more about being seen somewhere trendy than actually having genuine service and a good cup of coffee.

reviews.name: Joelle C.
reviews.review: I wish I could fly to Nashville right now and go to Barista Parlor.  It was a little difficult to find, but I love the ambiance!  Coffee is delicious!  I had the Salted Tennessee Whiskey Caramel Latte. So good! My friend had a waffle and said it was light and delicious! Fun to watch them make the coffee! For some reason I felt like I was transported back in time just looking at the Barista's and patrons! Very hipster! I love that they have local chocolates for sale. Love Barista Parlor!!

reviews.name: Ann W.
reviews.review: I just have to add that the last couple of times I went here I had a cappucino. One of the few places in the US that can make a cappucino like the Italians. Not too much foam. Not too much milk. Just right.

reviews.name: R S.
reviews.review: Two out of two for the coffee. It's awesome. Really. They don't locally source beans or roast in house, but they get great coffee. Stumptown and such. Employees are nice for the most part, but some treat you with a little bit of a too cool attitude / coffee snobbery. I used to work in a coffee shop that roasted in house and was very serious about coffee. I learned a lot there. One time I came to Barista Parlor and ordered an americano. The girl said "sorry, we can't make americanos." What? I was confused. "Why not" I asked. Her actual response was "it compromises the integrity of the bean." Well shit. Then she tried to make a case that their espresso machine is super high end and special and isn't capable of making americanos. Does it make espresso? Do you have hot water? Yes and Yes. Can I get them together in one cup? No. That's crazy to refuse to make a customer something they way they would like and explain it to them in a way that tells them "you do it wrong, moron." Anyway I didn't argue. It's just the way it was put. You should make what your customer asks for (unless it's a coffee milkshake or something like that). The other thing is that it can take up to 30 minutes to get a coffee. That's a real time I waited for a shot of espresso. They are slow and not just because of the V60 and Chemex brewing methods. Once I ordered an iced tea. They had the stuff pre made in their fridge. They mindlessly put the ticket in line and proceeded to make 2 Chemex brewed coffees which took over ten minutes. Then they made my iced tea in 10 seconds. (hint: that's not the efficient way to do that). There was also another employee walking around the counter doing little tidying tasks. They could have poured the iced tea, but they didn't. So, they could improve their timing, but I think they want it to be slow to make a point. I think that's actually their business model.I'll give them this, the last time I went in it was more pleasant. But you still have to wait for a long time for a coffee or espresso shot or whatever you order. Sometimes I want to go get a coffee from there, but I don't know how long I'll be waiting or what the employees will be like so I skip it and go to bongo java. It's just not worth the gamble.

reviews.name: Alicia O.
reviews.review: Such a great vibe. Staff is very helpful to explain coffee choices. Delicious coffee and the biscuits and gravy is NOT TO BE MISSED! Love this place.

reviews.name: R B.
reviews.review: Great coffee & food...it just takes FOREVER to get them though.  The ambiance is amazing...should definitely to there when the weather is warmer!

reviews.name: Cindy B.
reviews.review: Let me start by saying that I can't have caffeine, so I was not able to try the coffee. I had a nice tea instead.However, the seating in this place has ensured that I will never be back. There is a choice of low stools or high chairs, both with no back support. Then there are a few regular chairs at two community tables. Just as comfortable as sitting on the sidewalk. Sorry Charlie, you won't see me back there again.

reviews.name: J Q.
reviews.review: Smug arrogant hipsters. No artificial sweeteners in the place. Over priced. Mediocre coffee. I feel like that's all you need to know.

reviews.name: Matt L.
reviews.review: This is one of those cases in which you can admit that a place is a good place, but that it just doesn't appeal.  I've been all over Nashville to various coffee shops, and although I'll be the first to admit that Barista Parlor has a lot going for it, it just ticks me off personally.First, it seems to be needlessly expensive.  It charges for regular coffee drinks about the same as other places offer espresso drinks.  That's irritating.  Beyond that, the other things they were offering, like the chocolate, were outrageously expensive.  I knew the Olive and Sinclair is gong to be pricey, but they had a one inch wrapped chocolate, and when I asked the price, they told me a dollar!  A dollar, for one bite of chocolate?  Really?  Do I have to give them a pint of blood also?  Do I have to donate a finger, also.Beyond that, the place has this hipster vibe which translates to focusing on the coffee at the expense of ignoring customer service.  They're so laser-pointed on the product that there's little interaction.  When I used to frequent Roast Inc., they knew how to make the customer happy, even though they had a lot of focus on the drinks: Barista Parlor cannot do this.You may very well like this place: it's just not me.

reviews.name: Caitlin C.
reviews.review: Another one of those places everyone has been reading about in national articles about Nashville. A great place for coffee people - well coffee people who don't get uptight when they don't accommodate your preparation requests. I like the design aesthetic they went with and how they've set the counter up (there isn't one). If I were a coffee drinker I might be stopping here a lot but I'm not. We went to try their hot chocolate, which lacked any sweetness whatsoever. That's fine but there was nothing in the rest of the taste profile to make up for it, it just tasted like cocoa powder in milk. I may return or if I find myself nearby on the rare occasion that I decide to drink a coffee. I definitely want to try it and their iced ones look particularly enticing. I think if you're an out of towner it might be worth a visit, especially if you're in East Nasty. I liked the people watching and you can find every sort of hipster person here, enjoying their natural habitat. A solid spot in Nashville for sure.

reviews.name: Gabe F.
reviews.review: Excellent vibe. Hipster coffee. Mocha is great.

reviews.name: Boomarie C.
reviews.review: Coffee was so good I didn't need creamer!Ok, I occasionally like my coffee black - but seriously it was very good. Service was simple and the people are quite friendly.I highly enjoyed the environment as well! I'll be going back!

reviews.name: Hope D.
reviews.review: Let me start with the positives. Great cappuccino! I love the atmosphere and the decor is similar to my style. The stools are super cool and they used a lot of reclaimed wood rather creatively. I admire the iPad cash register and the built-in tax pricing system. They were in the process of developing a menu in partnership with Porter Road next door, so that's something to look forward to! Also, when you are waiting for your coffee to be prepared, they give you a "person" instead of a number to take to your table. After-all, we are people and not just numbers, right? ;)I'll admit it takes a few minutes to adapt when you enter this place. For a first timer, it's mildly confusing as there's not a typical counter area to place your order and also there's not an 'Open' sign outside. I'm not hard to please and I rarely expect much in America when it comes to customer service. I ordered a cappuccino, I liked it, I left, I'm a happy girl, the end. But, while I was there I overheard a customer who was saddened by the fact that something she wanted was not offered and the owner didn't seem at all concerned about her opinion. Then, I read another similar story in a review right here on Yelp. I completely understand that you cannot please everyone as a business owner in this day and age, but perhaps he could try a slightly more professional approach when dealing with customer feedback and the request is not downright outrageous? Just sayin'.

reviews.name: Lana L.
reviews.review: Amazing day!  I was in Nashville for business.  I flew in in the morning for a customer meeting in the late afternoon so needed a place to work for a while.  I yelped coffee shops and ended up here.  One of the best coffee shops I have ever been to.  I sat outside under some covered tables with a nice cool breeze and worked on my computer with vinyl records of Aretha Franklin and Barry White played in the background.  Very cool vibe and relaxing atmosphere.  I know where I'm going to be spending my day the next time I come in to visit this customer!

reviews.name: Jacob W.
reviews.review: I'm not the type to leave reviews because I don't expect perfection, but after today, the list of cons about this place has reached a breaking point.  My wife called me this morning from her sister's house where she's taking care of her sister's 3 children.  Exhausted, she asked me if I would run out and get her a Latte.  Later at Barista Parlor:"I'm ordering for my wife.  She'd like a Vanilla Latte with extra Vanilla Syrup to go.""We don't do that.""Really?  I can't order extra syrup?!""No. We don't do that here.  If you want it sweeter, you can go over there and add sugar.""I can't just have a little extra syrup?  It's syrup.  I'll pay for the extra charge.""You can go somewhere else and buy your own syrup and put it the drink.""I'll just go somewhere else."I left the parking lot but as I thought more about it, I just got angry at how rudely I'd been treated.  So I circled back in to talk with the manager.  She was the manager.  So I shared a piece of my mind."My wife has quit her job and has been taking care of her sister's kids for the last 8 months as her sister has battled breast cancer.  She exhausted and just wants a damn cup of coffee."  She finally offers to sell me what I asked for.  Not wanting to leave my wife waiting any longer, I bought the drink.  $6.50.Meanwhile, the guy I was going there to meet with had been waiting for his cup of tea for about 40 minutes.  He asked for a refund and we left.And that's just today.  The coffee is cold.  The service is unfriendly.  The $12 burgers are undercooked and served on a flat board that lets the salad dressing and burger juice flow into your lap.  And you can't eat anything without fighting off the flies.At Barista Parlor it's image over substance and the coffee is more important than you the customer.

reviews.name: Bluzzz S.
reviews.review: I don't know why I waited so long to drop in. I live in walking distance. I no longer work in the coffee biz but did so for 12 yrs and it was at 2 local coffee shops. I started in coffee pre starbucks era and I never cared for that type of coffee place. I want to taste my coffee when I drink it and not a ton of sugary syrup artificial junk that a lot of places tend to use now.          I found the atmosphere pleasant. There was a wide range of people there ranging in age from early 20's to 60's or so. People with their different electric devices, books ext or their dogs (outside) . Really nice old records playing. Nice lighting. It is spacious inside and not cramped.      I had the Cortado which is equal parts espresso and milk and the Southern Frenchman Biscuit. It had egg, Swiss cheese, really thinly sliced melt in your mouth ham and raspberry jam on it. Total cost was 12.25 including tax. The coffee was perfect, smooth and creamy without being bitter and the biscuit did absolutely melt in your mouth. The best biscuit i have had in Tennessee and i have lived here 22 yrs. My only complaint is that I wish the biscuit was a few bites larger for the price.      I will definitely be going back soon. If you want quality over quantity go here.

reviews.name: Tabitha T.
reviews.review: I saw friends tweeting pictures of their coffee mugs and finally, one morning, I agreed to make the "trek" to East Nashville to meet up with someone for breakfast. Boy am I glad I did! This gets 4 stars only because it was hard to find since there's no signage that's obvious or visible from Gallatin Avenue unless you're creeping along. Another reason is because, once you're there, you don't really know what your options are for coffee. It's not a huge problem, not a big deal at all and I have no qualms mostly because I am a coffee nerd and I don't need too terribly much instruction and I am not afraid to ask. However, some people want to know what they're getting right off the bat and hate asking questions and this may, on the first visit, be a tiny turn-off.Owner Andy Mumma is a coffee craftsman and he did say in an interview that he intended this to be the speakeasy of coffee shops. That may seem pretentious to some but one man's pretentiousness is this girl's gain - more good coffee for me!Food wise, their kitchen closes at noon so take that into consideration if you're planning to eat. The waffles are good - I ordered mine with a side of Porter Road Butcher sausage. The pastries are also made locally, and if you're on the go, grab a bar of chocolate to have with your coffee! They serve and sell coffee from good roasteries like Intelligentsia, Coava and Mad Cap and I highly recommend ordering the Intelligentsia brewed with the Hario V60 either hot or over ice. Honestly, just try it all. Sit and watch them brew your coffee, ask questions (the people who own it and the staff are SO nice, so friendly and ready to help you learn more about coffee) and treat yourself to some lovely brews. Pourover coffee is heavenly to drink. With the consistency of tea, it's smooth and goes down easily without any bitterness or too much acidity. So if you're looking for mud, stick to some of the older, local coffee places or Starbucks. If you're looking for delicious coffee (made right) and yummy food, go to Barista Parlor.

reviews.name: Amanda J.
reviews.review: I disliked this place. The parking was limited, there was confusion as to which way the line was forming (and the cashier was pretty rude at pointing that out), and everyone's holier-than-thou attitudes were making me feel like I was drowning in a large vat of Summer's Eve. From the time we walked in the door to the time we were delivered our two beverages, it was over 40 minutes. If I want a coffee, I don't feel like I should have to wait 40+ minutes for it (especially when it costs $15 for two 6oz beverages). Plus, the coffee was not even good...the iced Mast Brothers mocha that we ordered was separating (there were giant chunks of creamer floating in the drink and a mass of chocolate on the bottom). It wasn't stirred nearly at all and there was nothing provided to stir it with. This place's one single star goes towards the atmosphere, which was a pretty decent creative space. Everything else was really, really bad.

reviews.name: Jane D.
reviews.review: These folks take the coffee experience way seriously. But admittedly, its well deserved. A great cup of coffee deserves its sycophants and accolades, why not?  A stellar cappuccino. Lovely ambiance, nicest people working there, a special coffee place indeed.

reviews.name: Kendyl S.
reviews.review: I anxiously awaited Barista Parlors opening for months, watching their progress on instagram and facebook, reading about THE SLAYER machine, a super pricey espresso machine from Seattle, land of coffee. They finally opened! I went this morning for th 3rd time, first time I had a sample iced coffee, it was good. The second time I had a plain latte, also good, and today a vanilla latte. Very good! They also have a bourbon buttermilk waffle that sounds amazing. Plus they offer Almond milk! Sweet! The only downsides Ive seen are the wait times, its a little slow, but they are new so I forgive them, secondly the space is really huge and I know OMG "decorated" in there but it still feels a little cold and sparse, Its good for running in and out for coffee but not a place I want to sit and work. (if I did that kind of thing). I still need to explore their drip coffee options when I have more time.Anyway go check it out! A good addition to East Nashville and I imagine it will only get better with as they progress!

reviews.name: Scott B.
reviews.review: Barista Parlor is all decor and no substance.  It took 10 minutes for an average cappuccino and it was cold.  Also, they are buying all of their coffee out of state when they could be supporting the wonderful local coffee roasters in Nashville.  I've been to many coffeehouses around the world and Barista Parlor is average at best.

reviews.name: Randy M.
reviews.review: We have hit most coffee houses in Nashville and this place separates itself quickly. The vibe is mellow and hip. The coffee is top tier. The espresso is delicious and the staff friendly. If I lived here I would live here! The food is locally sourced and amazing. Get here now. Try the other spots first cause once you hit here you will be done.

reviews.name: Ben H.
reviews.review: One of the best coffee shops I've ever been in. The sausage biscuit was amazing and the coffee was fantastic. They were pouring intelligentsia, four barrel, counter culture, and stumptown when we were there. Cold brew was solid as well. Very highly suggest.

reviews.name: Jacob M.
reviews.review: Really cool shop, tons of seating, tons of great coffees from an assortment of roasters. The baristas are knowledgeable and helpful. I came by on the way into and out of Nashville (it is fairly close to the airport). I highly recommend the sausage biscuit w/ apricot(?) preserves. I also have a couple of friends who work here (unfortunately they were out of town the weekend I was travelling through), so make sure and be nice and leave large tips :)

reviews.name: Trevor A.
reviews.review: A slice of the Pacific Northwest in East Nashville, from the coffee culture, to the ambience, to the tattooed lumberjack hipster fashion show of most of the people in the room, I felt like I was back in SE Portland.  That is to say, this place is awesome.These guys know quality coffee, featuring premier artisan roasters from around the country, and their pour-over preparation lets the flavor profile shine.  The bean prices are a little steep for the average hipster budget, but their celebrity cast of beans are flying in fresh from around the country.  BP - how 'bout starting to roast your own?

reviews.name: Meg G.
reviews.review: I debated about how many stars to give Barista Parlor.  It isn't trying to be a pop-in, pop-out coffee house.  This is not where you go because you just need some caffeine to become human again and you would be happy licking the coffee rings off of your morning paper.  This place isn't about getting from point A to point B for your coffee, it is about the love of coffee.  If you just want a cup of coffee on your way home or out, or you normally drink Folgers at home, this place isn't for you.  So what is Barista Parlor trying to be?  It is trying to be artisan coffee and food.  Each cup of coffee is like a baby for them.  They nurture it and take care of it and each is unique.  It is no coincidence that they wear Imogene + Willie jeans.  This is the Napa Valley of coffee, not the Two Buck Chuck.  So rather than judging them based on what I think a coffee house should be, I will judge them by how well they achieved their goal.  This is why they get 4 stars--they are a pretty good example of what they set out to be.  The coffee is amazing and expensive if you were expecting the $1.95 five-hour-old mediocre stuff from Starbucks.  But I am willing to pay their prices when I want a delicious, intriguing,  and complex, much like a big cab wine from Napa.  Because they make each cup individually (ensuring freshness and quality) it takes a little longer.  Again, you want fast and cheap, go to a gas station.  There is no splenda or nutrasweet or anything like that.  Whatever, I don't really mind.  Just like there aren't french fries paired with a Napa red when you go for a tasting.  I don't care.  Once packet of sugar has like 20 calories so we can all chill and enjoy something real for once.  I had one of their breakfast sandwiches with local eggs, local Provence bread, PRB sausage made next door and local artisan cheese.  It was delicious.  Yes, it was a little too pricey, but if I wanted a cheap breakfast sandwich with ingredients that come from who-knows-where Factory and the Sysco truck, I could go to Nashville Biscuit House (which I also love, but is a different experience.)  They would get 5 stars from me if the breakfast sandwich was $6 instead of $8 (with the sausage.)  My coffee was great.  I had a drip style cup because that is what my husband prefers and he did the ordering.  Next time I will try an espresso.  I had the Coava that they were offering that day and it was really tasty.  I savored it slowly as I ate my sandwich.  I really dig the interior and the exterior.  Bold colors on the outside and a loft-y/garage-y feel on the inside.  It feels like a reclaimed motorcycle repair shop, which may be exactly what it is.  It oozes modern hipster cool.  There is a lot to look at and I liked the seating a lot.  Uncluttered and comfortable. We took our 5 month old and there were some other kids as well.  There were plenty of kidless, well-dressed hipsters and we all coexisted quite pleasantly.  One note of suggestion for Barista Parlor: some kind of board with the day's offering would be great so that while you are waiting in line you can be thinking about your order.  We had to wait until we were at the register to even look at the food and coffee selections and I felt rushed since there were a few people in line behind us.  Either that or print out you offerings and put some copies on clipboards along the line.  We will definitely be going back (since it is only a 5 minute walk from our house) but we may have to limit it to a once a week treat.

reviews.name: Kayla B.
reviews.review: I walked in and asked for a caffe breve. My request was arrogantly denied, and no alternative or comparable drink was suggested. I didn't know the barista parlor's baristas were menu stricken. Quite a let down. I guess I've spent 17$ on worse less satisfying things, but still. Really?

reviews.name: Jennie V.
reviews.review: My best friend flew into town and her flight landed mid morning on a Thursday. It was that weird, brunch time of day and being a weekday, our options weren't many. I had read good things about Barista Parlor, so off we went. I warned her that the place would be a bit hipster, but I had no idea what lay inside that wooden fenced in strip mall on Gallatin Road. The good: The food was delicious and the sweet barista was super friendly and helpful. The ingredients were all fresh and my iced "blush" tea was refreshing. The bad: The parking lot was confusing as all get out. It was like entering a doomsday prepper's back yard bug-in shelter and the spaces weren't marked... So, I maneuvered the vehicle on in and ended up sandwiched between a stage and some outdoor, tiki bar seating thing? Once you get inside, there are no signs directing you to the counter where you place your order. The baristas are just hanging out at this big 'ole island in the middle of the room and it's unclear as to where you are supposed to order and who you're supposed to be ordering from. The prices are a little high as well. Also, it takes a good while for you to get your food... I think we waited 20 minutes for a biscuit sandwich and BLT...  but no worries, you have a cut out piece of wood the size of a two year old to keep you company while you wait... I guess it signals where your order goes....  but it's a bit much. Finally, when you get your food, it is served on these teeny-tiny little cutting boards... Plates are too bourgeoisie? Overall, the food was good... the experience... interesting, but next time I want a biscuit sandwich, I'm hitting the drive through at Nashville Biscuit House.

reviews.name: Daniella B.
reviews.review: Great little coffee joint. Very hipster looking, the presentation of the coffee, menu, decoration is all on point, even the outfits if the people who live there. The coffee was great, and it looks like their baristas know what their doing, they make it look like an art. I do have to say that I felt that it was a little overpriced especially the chocolates. But overall very cool

reviews.name: Darren L.
reviews.review: It is what it is....Uber-Hipster. I actually don't require my coffee to come out of a Rolls-Royce  but every once in awhile I pop in with friends and have a great experience.. The utter pretentiousness is actually fun. At times I'm in the music biz so I applaud a healthy dose of snobbery and theater. Rock on with your leather aprons and Matthew Brady photo shoot extra looking servers...Rock on with your fancy overpriced java w/ chocolate & blueberry undertones....Rock on with your "under a rock" location....Rock on with your $7 dollar biscuits made with the cheese of  Himalayan Mountain Goats that are milked by the hands of temple virgins....Rock on Barista Parlor, Rock on!

reviews.name: E. D.
reviews.review: Best biscuits in town (and good coffee too)...

reviews.name: Tyler S.
reviews.review: For too long have I visited various coffee shops in the Nashville scene, only to be completely and utterly crushed by bad coffee and brewing methods. I can count on two hands the times I have asked so called "baristas" at so named "coffee shops" if they did pour overs, only to find a blank look.Barista Parlor has rekindled a hope in my coffee loving soul. As I walked in to the coffee shop, I immediately knew that it was going to be a winner. A shelf on the left had bags from my favorite coffee roaster, Counter Culture coffee, followed by the famous Stumptown coffee from Portland, Oregon. As I approached the barista and inquired as to my options, I was filled with information regarding coffee varieties, pour over options (hario v60, chemex, etc). I decided on the Teklu Dembel from Ethiopia per the friendly barista's suggestion, and was quite satisfied of the near-maximum extraction by the barista's skilled hands. In sum, I will now become a frequent visitor of Barista Parlor, and strongly recommend that any coffee lover, either a novice or expert, try this great venue.

reviews.name: Dave K.
reviews.review: I want to hate this place.  It's like hipster mecca.  No kidding, during our first stop to check it out, a white 15 passenger van pulled up and a load of hipsters rolled out.  Maybe it's just the 30-something father in me talking, that doesn't feel "cool enough" to be seen there. It feels elitist.  So when other reviewers say they "like the vibe" its because it's mainly composed of other people like them and not soccer moms on their way to drop/pick up their kids. (not that that's a bad thing)With that said, they make some freakin' good coffee.  I'm by no means an expert, but I'm gaining ground.  My wife and are in serious discussion about opening our own espresso bar in our home town, so wherever we go we check out the local brew.  To date, Barista Parlor takes the top prize.  The espresso machine they have makes me envious (a $18k+ Slayer).  I give partial credit to the machine, but a fair share must go to the Barista's.  I watched them work and they are good at what they do. We went with a simple Latte.  No flavor shots or specialty anything, just a straight latte.  With all of the raving, why 4 stars instead of 5?  It's simple.  They sell beans, but they can't/won't grind them for you.  My wife and I are from out of town, so we don't have access to our grinder.  We normally buy fresh beans at the local places and get them ground there.  But they couldn't/wouldn't do it.  Sure, they have 8 small grinders and 3 giant ones but they're all set for specific tasks and can't be bothered.  So...they lost our business.  This seems like such a rudimentary thing, I can't get over why they don't do it.Anyway, they make good coffee/espresso and if that's what you're looking for that's what you'll find.

reviews.name: I C.
reviews.review: I spent the last week in Nashville and have friends in East Nashville, one of them is a regular here. This was the best coffee I've had in a while and their attention to detail pays off. Normally I have my coffee with sugar and milk. I had the Stumptown Indonesia coffee and drank it black with the Mast Chocolate truffle bar (chocolate with Black truffle).  Then with a little bit of cream I had the same coffee with a lavender macaroon with lemon filling. The flavors with each combination and adjustment were noticeable. The space is conducive to working and people watching. Its a great addition to that side of town and coffee culture in Nashville.

reviews.name: Steve D.
reviews.review: Hated it.  They don't do long espresso shots.  Won't even give me hot water on the side. Instead they gave me an Americano which tasted like watered down crap and charged me $4.

reviews.name: M K.
reviews.review: I think a lot of positivity comes from so-called 'hipster' culture so I'm not one to be negative about it. Unfortunately this embodies everything that's wrong with hipster gentrification. $4 ice tea that took over 10min to arrive. In Nashville...not Bedford Ave. You just feel a bit silly really.

reviews.name: Matthew M.
reviews.review: Ok, I take back my earlier review.  I live in East Nashville now, and come here frequently.  The drinks are occasionally too tepid, but, apart from that, the espressos are masterful.

reviews.name: Glenn G.
reviews.review: Awesome retro hip coffee shop and more , the best chocolate cookie I have had in years!  Very cool , lp's on the turntable!

reviews.name: Jordan B.
reviews.review: This place is slightly hidden away behind a strip mall off Gallatin road.A great place for coffee.   It is worth paying a little more for a better tasting cup of coffee.They will craft each cup of coffee for you.  You get  a nice little glass pitcher and you mug.  I hear the food is great but I did not try it on this trip.They have wonderful community tables. around the counter and a few two person table tops around the side.The place has a very cool feel and very nice lighting.

reviews.name: C K.
reviews.review: Baristas are so pretentious and rude, i would avoid this place.  The food is pretty lousy.  But more than anything else, the people who work here are so snobby that it ruins any potential it could have to be a good, local hangout.  There is no authenticity or aliveness anywhere to be found here

reviews.name: Sumner G.
reviews.review: The ultimate hipster coffee bar - I am not a hipster coffee drinker but my daughter is. At first it was tricky to find because it's tucked away behind a clothing shop off Gallatin Road with the same address in the Inglewood/East Nashville area. They have converted an old garage and turned it into the ultimate place of cool including playing vinyl records and using reclaimed wood and local ingredients. The coffee is awesome (my daughters claims) - the hot chocolate is very good, but not sweet. This is not the kind of place you should take small kids - nothing for them to drink. The owners must not read the Yelp reviews about service and suggestions or they would have listened to our same issues over a year later. When we first went in, we didn't know if we were to sit down or walk to the cash register on the side of large dining room - no one greeted us and the small staff of 3 was busy making coffee for the full house. They need a sign at the front with an arrow pointing to "Order Here" and a menu of the day written out or printed. You do indeed go to the cash register (they need 2 cashiers) and order from a small wooden menu (they have 2 in the whole place I think) - very inefficient. We wanted "Peach Truck" Waffles, but they were sold out so we settled for cookies instead and java. They were excellent. Service was slow, but the quality is top notch. Hopefully, this little jewel will work on its weaknesses and continue growing in its strengths which is great coffee. And I hope they take note that hipster can equal both cool and "friendly".

reviews.name: Misty M.
reviews.review: Pretty good coffee, but not the best. I'm not sure why people go on and on about the place. It is a very nice place, but the coffee didn't super win me over. I've had better and I've had a lot worse. It was good, but not the best.

reviews.name: Justin R.
reviews.review: Hands down, best espresso in Nashville. No, really it is. If you don't believe me, he'd on over and taste it for yourself. At first glance, this place can be extremely overwhelming. Bright blue exterior with a few neon orange garage doors. From the outside, you might think this use to be an old body shop, and then when you walk inside, you realize that it was in fact an old body shop. I know some people might be intimidated by the extreme hipster vibe this place gives off, but you have nothing to worry about. The owners of this East Nasty spot are obviously miticlious about everything they do. From the coffee to the design of their store, everything is perfect. I love places that support the local economy. They have done a great job of encorporating various pieces of Nashville into their coffee shop. From local artists, to local chocolate makers, and everything in between. After all of this I haven't even mentioned the coffee yet. This is not a Starbucks. So, if you are looking to a tall extra cold vanilla Carmel non-fat carb free raspberry double extra frappacoffeechino, please save yourself the embarrassment and just go to your local Starbucks. But, if you are serious about you espresso, please let Barista Parlor show you what they do best. I'll say it again and again, best espresso in town!

reviews.name: Pon S.
reviews.review: I love, love, love this place! So cool, a garage turned restaurant, how cool is that! I the concept and the overall execution. It's cool how they brew coffee here and not to mention the variation they have of coffee is amazingly delicious.  Cool atmosphere, good service, and the coffee was delish. The food was okay, not worth the price but for the overall atmosphere of the place, it was worth the money I spent! Very unique place!

reviews.name: Brien W.
reviews.review: It's just ok, not crazy about the warehouse setting, might be too hip for me, especially when the coffee / espresso is just ok. Also hassled me about making a macchiato to go, we don't do that, we can make you a cortado to go!

reviews.name: Andre M.
reviews.review: Welcome to the most hipster coffee bar in Nashville. While normally that would come off as an insult, I genuinely like the Barista Parlor vibe. Yes, you will wait in line behind some of the most oddly clothed people you've ever seen. Yes, you will not know what you want to order because there are no menus. Yes, you will feel stupid because the menu can only be read by the most knowledgable coffee drinkers. But... You will have great coffee, you will have great food (I recommend the sausage biscuit - delicious!), and you will enjoy yourself. Don't look for a particular comfy place to sit, but the furniture is hip and there is free wifi. One of my favorite hipster coffee shops.

reviews.name: Anne F.
reviews.review: It doesn't get any more hip than this, y'all. When Barista Parlor anchored itself up on the East Side, it was the only thing I heard about for weeks on end. Inside this renovated warehouse on Gallatin is a space for every 37206er or wannabe to come get their caffeine fix. Even if you aren't cool, you'll feel cool once you walk inside.  As far as coffee goes, a specialty drink will cost you upwards of $5 (at least) and, if you want a souvenir to take home, a mug will cost you $25. Don't let that keep you from putting the baristas to work at least once, though... that Iced-Salted-Tennessee-Whiskey-Caramel-Latte might've been the most refreshing drink I've ever tasted.

reviews.name: Mike F.
reviews.review: Exactly the kind of coffee joint that East Nashville needed. Next to Crema, it's really the only decent cup of black robot juice that's worth a damn in this city. The espresso is thick and muddy, and loaded with flavor. Even the iced coffee is great (though I feel like they cringe when you order it).I dock one star for the amount of time it takes to get served here. Every time I've gone in, it takes 15-20 minutes to get a cup of coffee. And while I'm happy to wait for a great piece of caffeine, it means I can't stop in here on my way to a meeting.And that, my friends, is why every single day I wonder why there is no drive through coffee joint in East Nashville. Somebody, please, make it happen.

reviews.name: Ian R.
reviews.review: This is another one of those establishments that does not need a great number of words to describe it.  Simply Exceptional is really all you need to know.  If you don't like it you don't get it.

reviews.name: TJ W.
reviews.review: Wonderful coffee (they do pour over style) and espresso, possibly the best in Nashville. Cool aesthetics (coolest I've seen in a cafe anywhere). This is a place for coffee lovers and those who like a really pleasing and wide open work/leisure environment.

reviews.name: Michelle P.
reviews.review: Awesome atmosphere. Cool people. I'd return. My two complaints are: no decaf (maybe people don't mind this) & coffee was ok considering how much they charge ($4 + optional tip...although rarely does it feel optional anymore).  Great to bring my baby to.

reviews.name: Adam N.
reviews.review: I'm not a coffee drinker, so I can't speak to that, but I came here looking for a good place to work. The atmosphere is really nice. I also ordered a burger which was good, if a little overpriced. But the Wi-FI here blows. If you need a reliable place to work with good Wi-Fi, look elsewhere.

reviews.name: Katie M.
reviews.review: If you want to drink great coffee, you have to make a trip to the Barista Parlor in East Nashville.  The pecan bars are heavenly!

reviews.name: Anna B.
reviews.review: This place is beyond pretentious and honestly, I've been to a number of serious coffee houses living in NYC, but this shop just takes the cake. I came here on a Saturday afternoon with someone and we waited about 15 minutes to receive our drinks after ordering. They also don't make Americanos which is so strange considering that is a common thing at every coffee shop. Upside is the staff is very friendly and my cold brew was actually delicious. Would I go back? Probably not.

reviews.name: John P.
reviews.review: They care about everything more than you do.  Recommended: Sausage Biscuit (with Jelly) and a ' Madcap' or an Iced Vanilla Latte.  Exceptionally good

reviews.name: Jonathan S.
reviews.review: Hands down best sausage biscuit in the entire city! So good, I'll drive from Bellevue to have it.

reviews.name: Sloane S.
reviews.review: Go. Visit. Hipster mecca. Coffee is superb. Currently addicted to the Bourbon latte. Their rosemary scones are worth the extra workout. Plenty of parking. Love the decor. Oh, and did I mention the chocolate? When I need a good fix (and that is often), it's the first place I go.

reviews.name: Sara D.
reviews.review: First off, It took me a hot second to figure out where the place was. Coming from the north side you will pass it. When I walked in I instantly loved the openness and helpful hipsters behind the counter. It's like everyone before me has said - Yes, there are copious amounts of hipsters all dressed alike, but you'll see some other neighborhood types there too. Everyone's there for the same reason, they need their fix of their favorite legal addictive stimulant. I'm pretty particular about my coffee and espresso beverages. I judge a place first by their cappuccino. If it's not worth it, i won't go out of my was for ya and just head to Starbucks or Bongo Java for quick fix. I have to give them an A+. The ratio of sweet espresso, milk and foam was perfect. The baristas take real pride in their work, and even though it takes an extra minute, it's totally worth it.  The coffee isn't polluted by the good ol'  BUNN coffee pot. It's made to order and perfectly balanced as well. It's like "nectar of the gods" kind of quality!  Overall, this place rocks, and I've found a new hang out. Thanks Barista Parlor for being my first Yelp review!

reviews.name: S C.
reviews.review: Excellent neighborhood coffee spot-- especially when the weather is nice (the outdoor seating is a huge plus).  The service is always friendly, the drip coffee is very tasty (though I have always been a bit disappointed by the lattes-- and I wish there was a larger option for to go drinks), and the decor is unique and beautiful.

reviews.name: Janet S.
reviews.review: Walked in at a 1.45pm, closes at 2.00pm.  A cluster of what looked like male servers eyed us up, dismissed us and carried on their conversation, no hey up how are you then, fancy a coffee.  Huge uncomfortable sterile  looking space, not for us at all, biscuits with porter road butcher something inside, blimey said pablo, that's a bit expensive.  Can't actually speak about the coffee as we just walked out again.  Looks like it might become the Red Door of Coffee houses.

reviews.name: Brandon H.
reviews.review: This is the house of coffee purists and hipsters around east Nashville.  If you want to order from a quick to go spot, this isn't your place, but if you have some time it's worth the wait for sure!

reviews.name: Tyler W.
reviews.review: This is for the real coffee lover.  Think about it like you are drinking a glass of wine instead of an espresso.  This could be a good thing or a bad thing.  If you normally enjoy Boones Farm aka McD's McCafe this place will probably fall on deaf ears, but if your an avid lover of high quality coffee this is your place.  I enjoyed my machiato and my wifes cappacino was very good.  I didn't get to try any of the chocolate, but it looked like a hard core selection from some fancy purveyors.  The staff was helpful, because the flow of the ordering process is a little different, but they were accomodating.  The interior space is awesome, and you can tell they dropped a dime polishing up this place.  I love the fact that they include tax in your price.  If you order a $3 drink...then it's gonna cost you $3.  Thats a simple thing, but I love that, so kudos to you guys.Also..don't forget to wear your plaid shirt/skinny jeans...they require it at the door, I believe a mustache and bowler cap is acceptable as well, or at least thats the way it seems.  Its a hippster paradise.

reviews.name: Tnvd C.
reviews.review: Okay, so I haven't been since the summer, so maybe things have changed..but from my experience, Barista Parlor is pretentious-city. Within two minutes of being inside the establishment, you've probably noted five people insta-graming their drinks. The coffee is likely four-stars, but what IS two stars is the way the baristas act toward their customers if they are not part of the race to see who knows more about overpriced coffee. Maybe they were having a bad day, but in my experiences in public service, it isn't very nice to scoff at people who are going to be handing you money in a minute. My girlfriend came with me (she isn't much of a coffee drinker) and asked if they had any teas. She was essentially baby-talked and mansplained to in a chivalrous way about how they only serve COFFEEEEEeeee and seemed to sugest that she was an idiot for thinking otherwise. I got a fancy-ass mocha-thing. It was served in a mason-jar and cost me six dollars. The ice was pretty cool and had science in it, except there was too much of it, so I really paid the most for frozen water. The coffee was rather good, but when you're going to a place for an 'experience' or to try something new, I wish people were nicer and a tad friendlier.

reviews.name: Sam P.
reviews.review: Coffee tastes nice. The decoration is neat...but I will not be back. The vibe is just WAY to snooty and hoity toity.I give it 1 normal thumb up.....and 2 hipster thumbs up.Its kinda like neck tattoos....neat to look at, but only hipsters will really love it.

reviews.name: Dwayne H.
reviews.review: This may be the coolest coffee shop ever! Sit at long tables with tons of character & high ceilings. I had the Ethiopian coffee and it was excellent. I think they serve sandwiches, muffins & fine chocolate. A must find in Nashville!

reviews.name: Colleen T.
reviews.review: Yaye! A new coffee shop less than a block from my house!I love it! delicious delicious coffee.love the mason jars for my iced coffee as well.Would love it if they would offer SOME sort of 2nd cup discount. I understand that they brew each cup one by one (which i was super impressed by, and I am into it!), but even a $2.50 second cup would have enticed me to go for another!can't wait to try some food! I'll definitely be a regular of this place!

reviews.name: Laini B.
reviews.review: If you want a cup of good strong coffee this is the place to go.  Was a little disappointed when we asked for additional caramel we were told no, didn't really understand the explanation given as to why we would have to order a whole drink to get some more...

reviews.name: Heather S.
reviews.review: The Bourbon barrel vanilla latte w/almond milk (iced) is one of the best lattes I've ever had - BUT for $5 I wish the cup was bigger!

reviews.name: Laura T.
reviews.review: yummy sausage biscuit with apple butter and delish coffee with great flavors!!

reviews.name: Lauren A.
reviews.review: This place may be hard to find at first, as its tucked away behind a strip mall off Gallatin, but maybe that will help keep it from getting too crowded as I can tell this place will be very popular.  I'm excited to have a coffee shop like this in East Nashville, minutes from my house!  They use all hatcher milk, and local chocolate for their mochas..  They also give you plenty of options for your choice of coffee.  Coffee prices are reasonable for what you're getting, its an individually crafted cup of coffee..  You won't see coffee urns in this place.  They also have a small menu featuring local meats and baked treats as well - sausage biscuits, buttermilk waffle, fruit cups, etc.  The interior of the place is really nicely done - it reminds me a lot of Four Barrel in San Francisco - very modern, minimalist, lots of chunky wood and industrial lighting.  I can see myself visiting this place often, even though I work at another coffee shop!

reviews.name: Adam B.
reviews.review: This place is rad.  Really good vibe, and an excellent selection of roasters available from across the country.  On a trip across country I cleved off a day to hang out in Nashville to sample the local cafes and pull in Climb Nashville, and I'm super glad I did.  This café is a great addition to an already cool town, especially since they offer siphon brewing, always a treat.  I was psyched to see Sightglass, Coava, Counter Culture, and Mad Cap gracing the shelves @ Barista Parlor, especially since I had never had the experience of sampling anything from Mad Cap before.  They also work off a Slayer, which is always a pleasure to have a shot off, and as usual it didn't disappoint.  Talked with the barista about other spots to hit in town and he was super helpful and directed us to a couple other stellar cafes.  They're selection of chocolate was also excellent, nice to see Mast Bros. making an appearance (proceed to stuff-face), as well as other more local southern products.  My wife and I both sampled the Ethiopian Ardi from Mad Cap and I was pretty impressed.  Light and vibrant with acidic high notes, it made my morning.  I capped it off with a shot of Coava off the Slayer and I felt like a new man after being trapped in the car for the previous 3 days.  I was a little bummed to see that the roast dates on the Mad Cap they were offering for sale where out a few weeks, but there were only 2 bags left, so I assume they were cycling it out for another offering.  Other beans were fresh.  These guys will be my go-to spot in Nashville when I'm there, no doubt, I could have hung out all day if the thought of pulling plastic at Climb Nashville wasn't twirling in the back of my head.

reviews.name: Adrianna F.
reviews.review: I've been in there twice asking for decaf and they basically scoffed at me. Like some other yelpers who reviewed Barista Parlor, I can't drink caffeine for health reasons, but I do love me some coffee. The employee I spoke with said that they hadn't found a decaf of high quality, so they do not offer it. I understand wanting to maintain the integrity of your store, but I'm not sure that not providing decaf at all is the way to go. I am SURE that there are good decaf options out there. I'd say that the BP should actually invest some time and effort picking a great decaf. Not only would us non-caffeine drinkers appreciate it, but also the BP wouldn't lose out on my business or the business of my friends who don't go there because we are unable to enjoy a coffee together.

reviews.name: S H.
reviews.review: Was in town for the weekend and hanging in the trendy east end. Wanted to try a new coffee house and saw this place on yelp. The pics don't lie. The environment is super hipster, organic and cool. All of that was overtaken by a 25 minute wait to have hot water poured by hand over the coffee grounds to make my personal cup of coffee. It was good coffee but not worth $3.50 or the wait. There is no reason for one guy to be pouring water on three coffees at a time. A French press would have been quicker. This was way too over the top in trying to be unique and trendy... A latte probably had a 45 minute wait.

reviews.name: David G.
reviews.review: I recently started drinking caffeine in my coffee again, after two years of sticking with decaf. It was a tough decision - I don't like being a slave to my addiction, but the coffee choices are broader and the Alzheimer's studies are compelling, so here I am. Conveniently, that makes Barista Parlor a perfect place for me now. I am exactly the type of coffee drinker they cater to - obsessed with high quality, recently roasted beans prepared with good single-cup brewing methods. And so, I will be going to Barista Parlor regularly, because they serve me very, very well. And the food menu with all locally-sourced components is exquisite - expensive, but worth every penny.So why 3 stars? 3 reasons.1) They don't have any locally roasted coffee choices. Now, I know that our local roasters are not necessarily all great, but I've tasted nearly every coffee from Roast, Inc. and certainly think at least one or two of them could compete with the coffees Barista Parlor serves. They support (and allow their customers to support) local businesses with their food menu and chocoloate options (despite the fact that Olive and Sinclair is really not quite up to the standard of their other chocolates), so why not offer at least one local option?2) No decaf. When Barista Parlor was about to open, I had a conversation with the owner about this - basically, it was pretty clear from his demeanor that he thinks decaf coffees can't possibly compete with caffeinated coffees. He is wrong. Counter Culture, Coava, Intelligentsia, and, yes, Roast Inc. all sell decaffeinated coffees that are just as delicious, complex, and expensive as the coffees Barista parlor currently sells. Some of them are even single-origin, though admittedly blends are more common. Even if he tastes them all and disagrees (and I'm certain he hasn't), why not at least offer a decaf espresso? I promise, whatever quality difference his discerning palate can find will be drowned out by the milk and sugar in a latte, and preparation is 90% of a good espresso anyway. Now that they are open later, this seems like even more of a problem - I would love a cup of coffee at 4 pm, but I can't drink caffeine that late if I want to sleep. I'm sure I'm not alone. 3) Demeanor. Okay, you don't want to offer decaf, soy milk, or Splenda - fine. I think you're nuts - personally, I only drink coffee black, but I still wouldn't open a coffee shop without milk or sugar out of some weird desire to bring people around to my opinion, because I respect others' opinions - but it's your business. Find a way to stand by your decisions without making your customers feel like yokels. If they're talking to you about your decisions, it means they want your product - well-prepared, high quality coffee - and are willing to pay the justifiably exorbitant prices to do so. Treat them like crap, and they're very likely never to return.

reviews.name: Carriga C.
reviews.review: cool atmosphere and normally somewhere i would like to go. definitely trying in every way to come across as super hipster (hidden away behind a strip mall in an old car garage, artisan light bulbs hanging everywhere and distressed everything...like it came straight out of an episode of portlandia), which evidently includes the owners attitude toward customers...no soy milk...only almond, which is a bummer when youre allergic to almonds...read a couple of other reviews that said that the owner really doesnt care that there are people who cant have or dont want almond milk and would prefer soy...fine i guess, but what happens if youre unhappy with something else?

reviews.name: Housecharmer C.
reviews.review: I might add to Michael P's review below which was spot on and hilarious for us...I do get the purity of this place but this is my morning jolt!  I have been around great coffee since I opened one of the first coffee bars in San Francisco in 1972. I just can't help myself thinking like a business owner when I'm here in line at Barista Parlor,calculating...Uh oh. slow line means poor planning, service, and lost revenue. Maybe the owner doesn't care? OK then. How many people are discouraged when they see the line? Lost income? One never knows.Empty tables and a line? OMG!  Would it kill the decor to put out six menus or write a chalk board? I think not.I try not focusing on the negative so I cruise the decor. Fabulous. But where IS that menu so I can use everyone's time effectively? No I have to wait 20 minutes to see that until I'm at the decorative till. I see the menu and it's thankfully very decorative. What do I want? I have to "read it" and edit all the flourishy" local" descriptions to find the actual food items hidden in the copy, and it's MY TURN! Oh God please make me decisive,easy and fast!  So annoying. "Move On" to myself. I see cold extracted coffee. Perfect. Low acid great taste is what I want and so I expect "toddylike" no BS. I sit down and wait 10 minutes (time elapsed 30) for my coffee. Well this is one is Japanese wtf method so I get mine on ICE! Really? I must have missed the memo. I didn't want my coffee iced. Excuse me Barista but is there something I missed? Maybe you serve this iced for some reason? He shrugged. I am not to know. Do I want to wait 10 more minutes for hot? No. Ok then. This isn't Zappos. I drink the iced coffee which the server should have replaced with hot immediately. 10 minutes later we get our food. Mine looks beautifully Spartan and local handmade yadayada. YUM. I unwrap my napkin for utensils and there are none. My biscuit sandwich is 4 inches high. it would have been nice! Go get them. Go get sugar for everyone. Go get water. Darnit. I paid a gratuity at the decorative till! Fool.There is a utensil and decor nazi lurking here. Oh! they have retail items here on the walls. no. wait. no prices. are they for sale? We are not telling you (decor nazi strikes again.) Be happy with the decor and the impressive barista elixir and foam but expect marginal personal service, and only pretty good food. Bakery items,sausage,and chocolate were great. I only wish the owner could come here and stand in the shoes of a customer. Paying a couple more servers wouldn't kill you. You would increase your volume.This place could have been so much more. I really wanted to love this place.Dang. Meh.2.

reviews.name: Sarah M.
reviews.review: They are a bit hidden and not in the most ideal location, but inside it's a really great environment...very open and airy.  I would recommend more smaller tables for parties of 3 or 4...it's either huge tables or only 2-seaters.  The cappuccino was delicious and very hot, and the sausage and egg biscuit was delicious.  Sausage was a bit on the strong side for my taste, but you could tell it was fresh.

reviews.name: Sherie B.
reviews.review: Visited for the first time this week and would go back again. It is not near my house so it wouldn't be on a regular basis but definitely would go back. It was a very different experience for me.We had a hard time determining where the entrance is located. We were told "right behind the butcher shop" so that helped and then there is a big arrow and a sign that says "Barista Parlor" but there is nothing near the door to indicate that this is actually it. It doesn't look like a coffee shop from the exterior but once we did get in, we were very impressed.I love the atmosphere. It is big, open, airy, and the garage doors on the front wall give it a very unique look.The latte I had was one of the best I've ever had and the server at the counter was very friendly and helpful with suggestions. My daughter had the sausage biscuit and enjoyed it very much. The sausage was just spicy enough (I had a bite).I agree with one of the other reviewers about the chocolate prices. Way too high!

reviews.name: Frank M.
reviews.review: Hands down, best coffee and selection in Nashville.  Every espresso and pourover I've ordered has been close to flawless.  In addition, the large number of roasters that they feature means that I never get bored with any coffees before they change them.  Andy and all of the baristas are extremely nice and helpful.  They make great recommendations if you're new to specialty coffee and they'll talk for hours about the subtle differences in varietals if that's what you're into.

reviews.name: Latanya C.
reviews.review: Fantastic wings! Not greasy at all. Really good tots...crispy outside, warm and tender inside! Great service. Curly, the owner, is friendly and passionate about his food. We got carry out, but sat there and ate all 16 wings before we left! We then got even more food to go. We'll be back!

reviews.name: M H.
reviews.review: I'm so happy to find a place that delivers in Antioch other than pizza or Chinese! I ordered the bacon blanket big boy burger, tater tots, small vanilla milkshake & what I THOUGHT was a large slice of red velvet cake. I later found out that it's actually a red velvet cake milkshake. (Not their fault. I just misread.)-The burger & tots were great! Definitely not a fast food chain!-The vanilla shake was "meh".-The red velvet shake was great! Loved the chunks of cake mixed in.My only complaints are cost & time. A $28.00 total for a burger, tots & 2 shakes is pretty steep. Still, I'm someone that will pay for convenience so I imagine this will become a regular ordering place for me.It took 70 minutes to get my order so that's the real reason I deducted a star. Not that big of a deal really, just be forewarned that it may take a bit. I got a message from the EAT24 app that it would take an hour because of it being peak dinner time. I suppose it is a good sign that it was a busy time for them.The delivery man was very nice, which is refreshing after a slew of rude delivery people from my local Chinese delivery spot.I will definitely be ordering from them again.

reviews.name: Joanne R.
reviews.review: I have been to Curley's twice and it is a solid restaurant with good food and great customer service. The wings are fresh and cooked to order and the sauces I have tried are delicious.  My favorite is the barbecue and the garlic parmesan is a close second. Today I had the bacon blanket burger and fries.The burger was fresh and very well seasoned. They weave the bacon into a sheet so it covers the entire burger. The bun is bakery fresh and the burger fixings are balanced nicely.  Regrettably, the fries were overcooked and greasy. A pleasant surprise was the house made fruit punch. It was delicious. A nice balance of tangy and sweet, it was quite refreshing.  Overall it is a good place to get good wings and great customer service.

reviews.name: Jayna J.
reviews.review: 1st, they offer GREAT customer service, which is hard to come by these days (unfortunately)!2nd, their wing flavors are homemade. And the few we had tried are delicious! 3rd and lastly, I just finished THE BEST Red Velvet "Cake Shake" EVER!!We are happy to have found a new spot in Antioch!

reviews.name: Inas W.
reviews.review: The owner showed me ALOT of pics of his burger on toast. Trying to Oversell his food. Then said I won a "door prize" a MENU...really! Then he highly encouraged me to get this "special" sauce for his "jumbo" wings....which were FAR from JUMBO. He was very talkative about mediocre at best for the food.

reviews.name: Raquel M.
reviews.review: Wings were awesome, definitely try the hot honey sauce. I loved them. I'll definitely be going back to get some more. Next time I'll get the jumbo wings because I accidentally ordered the smaller size not knowing how small they'd actually be.

reviews.name: Veronica S.
reviews.review: I tried Curley's Carryout for the first time yesterday! Omg! The Honey hot whole wings were soooo good! I had leftovers for work today.  Now I just placed an order for dinner tonight. They are so worth eating two days in a row.  If you have tried this place you really need to. Wonderful wings!!

reviews.name: Nick N.
reviews.review: Food is prepared to order so wait time can be fairly extensive as you could expect. The wings were baked very well and tasted excellent and the red velvet milkshake was one of the best shakes I've ever had.

reviews.name: Foodie O.
reviews.review: Can't say enough good things about this place. Everything I've had is good!! Wings, fish, pull pork fries...Oh and the burgers!! The burgers are real deal!! Not all that thick packie burger you get from the other places. These burgers are seasoned well and fresh meat. They have me as a customer as long as they're around.

reviews.name: Bristol C.
reviews.review: all i can say is "you have to try the garlic parmesan wings"!!!!!

reviews.name: Eric E.
reviews.review: This place is incredible.  Some of the best wings I've ever had. We had honey hot and golden tangy and both were done just right. The sauces were incredible and the wings seemed to have been smoked first. The place lacks in atmosphere, the furniture is falling apart and gross so I would describe this as a hole-in-the-wall hooters but with a slightly different uniform for the gals. If you can handle yourself in a potentially uncomfortable atmosphere and get over the bad furniture you will be delighted with the food coming out of the kitchen. Also try the 1/4 chicken-it was fall off the bone delicious. Only other negative was the sauces came in kraft packets versus in small cups- even though it's the same stuff in a different restaurant the presentation was low class

reviews.name: Victoria H.
reviews.review: Love me some Donk wings. Golden Tangy & Honey Hot are my favorite! Also the Chicken Quesdilla & fries are fye. I would agree w/ one of the reviews tho about the drinks being served in plastic cups & waiters having no knowledge of drink specials or what's in them. They should invest in a drink menu 2 advertise the bar better. But I wouldn't say Hooters wings are NOT better than Donks. I went there 4 the 1st time today & was wishing I had went 2 Donks.

reviews.name: Dee B.
reviews.review: So it's okay. I'm not super crazy about this place. One of those, if you gone once, it's all good. Not hurry back. I tried the honey hot, lemon pepper, and buffalo chicken wings. The lemon pepper was super salty. It's a dry rub seasoning. The honey hot was okay. The buffalo was alright. Taste like any other hot wing. It's definitely not Hooters. They don't have an alcoholic drink menu and the waitress couldn't tell you what's in their supposedly popular mix drinks they call Donk Twister. And their so-called mix drink specials isn't exactly advertised properly. The waitress said 2*4*1 mix drinks but a jack & coke didn't qualify. Makes no sense. Paid $28 for 4 drinks. This was retarded. And the drinks was served in those tiny plastic cups served in the clubs. Better off drinking a beer, if there's a next time. We shall see.

reviews.name: Brian Y.
reviews.review: Came here when they opened right at noon on a Sunday while visiting town with two friends.  Didn't expect a crowd, so wasn't disappointed when there were just a few people in the house.Between the three of us, we got fried catfish, wings, a burger and a chicken wrap, which were all good.  The fried pickles were battered too thick, but still tasty.Most of the stars in this review go to our waitress/bartender, Jazzy.  She and the rest of the staff were really fun and easy to talk to, even the guy in the kitchen.  Jazzy served us up some of their house specialty ("Liquid Marijuana") back in the VIP, surrounded by pictures of the bar's namesake.  It was some sort of drink involving what we think was vodka, pineapple juice and green kool aid.  Delicious.

reviews.name: Mark W.
reviews.review: Great sports bar in Nashville .I have been for lunch and late night when It turns into a club.Donks is  an urban version of a hooters .Girls shorts say DONKS on the backWings are great as is the fish.Next time I go I may have to get a turkey legGreat place to go on a Sunday .NFL package!

reviews.name: Foody P.
reviews.review: The place is disgusting, I mean the FOOD! I see reviews on the wings and TRUST ME! It's no WING STOP, no KNOCK OUT WINGS, no HOOTERS. The drinks.... YUK. My friend had a burger and she got sick when we got back to our dorm. The waiters are FAT AF &' UGLY NASHVILLE MESS. Smh HORRID!!!

reviews.name: Eric F.
reviews.review: Nice place to visit and have a drink!!  The owner greeted everyone that came in and chatted with everyone!!!  The service was GREAT!!!!!!

reviews.name: Stephen H.
reviews.review: I showed up at Donk's with a party of 10 after driving for 7 hours from Columbus OH. We walked in the door and were greeted by at least 3 total strangers warmly welcoming us. I immediately knew we were in for a treat. Juicy took care of us and brought us delicious fries and 5 different types of wings. I particularly enjoyed the fried pickles. This place is not Hooters. It's low key and classy. The food is good and the atmosphere is excellent. There is pool, sports and karaoke. Also excellent Happy Hour specials. I will absolutely be returning in the future. Thanks Juicy!

reviews.name: Stephen S.
reviews.review: Went to Donks for my lunch hour. I ordered 10 wings, no fries and a Coke Zero. 10 bucks for the wings, 2 for the coke. The wings were big, the buffalo was hot, but not too hot. I really enjoyed them! I'l be back for sure.

reviews.name: T S.
reviews.review: Donks was honking awesome! We showed up with 11 dudes and got white boy waisted. Great food! Great service! Its like hooters but opposite and better food!

reviews.name: Lawrence C.
reviews.review: I was looking for a place to watch a NBA basketball and I had asked around about a good place to check out. I was told I should check out Donks, but with a warning. I was told on certain nights, it can get a little rough. Don't have an issue with hood as long as everyone is having a good time. Not trying to die over it. The waitresses were very attractive( Beautiful Black Women) so that was a plus. I thought the DJ was on point. He played Rap music during the commercial. I would go again.

reviews.name: Carla T.
reviews.review: if your in the mood for a quick drink, a lil music or even pizza, chicken tenders and donkey legs (turkey legs) this is the perfect spot. i love to visit Donks! its in my neighborhood for 1 and its also like cheers every time i walk in the door. you have activity in just about every corner and you are free to mingle with friends or just chill at the bar or in a corner table.
